title: David Perdue
added: In October 2020, Perdue made international news<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/republican-senator-perdue-s-mocking-mispronunciation-of-kamala-harris-name-earns-him-flak/story-SM63GwuX8pdgugIpc5dxPL.html|title=Republican senator Perdue's mocking 'mispronunciation' of Kamala Harris' name earns him flak|date=October 17, 2020|website=Hindustan Times}}</ref><ref>https://www.gulftoday.ae/news/2020/10/17/republican-senator-perdue-mocks-kamala-harris-name-at-trump-rally</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/north-america/gop-senator-mispronounces-kamala-harris-name-at-trump-rally-20201017-p5660i.html|title='Kamala-mala-mala': GOP senator mangles Kamala Harris' name at Trump rally|first=Will|last=Weissert|date=October 17, 2020|website=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> by mocking Democratic Vice Presidential nominee [[Kamala Harris]] by repeatedly mispronouncing her name, which is of [[South Asian]] origin. In the campaign appearance, Perdue called Harris "Kah-mah-la or Kah-ma-la or Kamamboamamla", which drew scattered laughter from the crowd. Commentators noted that Perdue, who has served with Harris in the Senate since 2017, undoubtedly knows how to pronounce her name, and some said he deliberately pretended otherwise to appeal to a largely white audience.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Politi|first1=Daniel|title=Sen. Perdue Mocks Kamala Harris' Name at Trump Rally|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/10/david-perdue-mocks-kamala-harris-name-trump-rally.html|accessdate=17 October 2020|website=Slate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Press|first1=Associated Press|title=Republican senator faces backlash after mocking colleague Kamala Harris' name|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2020-10-16/senator-perdue-backlash-butchering-kamala-harris-name|accessdate=17 October 2020|website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Danner|first1=Chas|title=GOP Senator David Perdue Deliberately Butchers 'Kamala' at Georgia Trump Rally|url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/senator-perdue-deliberately-butchers-kamala-at-trump-rally.html|accessdate=17 October 2020|website=New York Magazine}}</ref> A spokesman for Perdue responded to the criticism, "Senator Perdue simply mispronounced Senator Harris's name, and he didn't mean anything by it."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/10/16/georgia-sen-perdue-faces-criticism-after-mocking-kamala-harris-name/3686517001/|title=Georgia GOP Sen. Perdue faces criticism after 'mockingly' mispronouncing Kamala Harris' name|first=Savannah|last=Behrmann|website=USA TODAY}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/david-perdue-republican-senator-criticized-for-repeatedly-mispronouncing-kamala-harris-name-at-rally/|title=Republican senator repeatedly mispronounces Kamala Harris' name at Trump rally|website=www.cbsnews.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/16/politics/david-perdue-kamala-harris/index.html|title=Georgia Republican senator willfully mispronounces Kamala Harris' name at Trump rally|first1=Donald |last1=Judd |first2=Ryan |last2=Nobles |website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/16/david-perdue-mocks-kamala-harris-name-429996|title=David Perdue mocks Kamala Harris' name in Trump rally warm-up|first=Matthew|last=Choi|website=[[Politico]] |date=2020-10-16 }}</ref>

title: David Perdue
added: On October 13, 2018, Perdue visited the [[Georgia Tech]] campus to campaign for gubernatorial candidate [[Brian Kemp]]. During his visit, a Georgia Tech student approached Perdue and asked him a question about voter suppression. Perdue snatched away the student's phone, which was recording the exchange.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/10/14/senator-snatched-students-phone-while-being-asked-about-georgia-voter-registration-uproar/?noredirect=on|title=Senator Snatched Student's Phone While Being Asked About Georgia Voter Registration Uproar|author=Wang, Amy B.|date=October 14, 2018|work=Washington Post}}</ref> The student filed civil suit, alleging unlawful battery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/22/politics/georgia-tech-student-lawsuit-cell-phone-senator-perdue/index.html|title=Georgia Tech student sues Sen. Perdue after cell phone flap|first=Kate |last=Sullivan |website=CNN}}</ref>

title: David Perdue
added: On November 13, Perdue attended a packed campaign event in Cummings, Georgia alongside Senators [[Rick Scott]] and [[Kelly Loeffler]], both of whom would [[White House COVID-19 outbreak|later test positive for COVID-19]].<ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rick-scott-covid-19-positive/</ref>  On November 20, Perdue and Loeffler held a campaign event with Mike Pence in Canton, Georgia.<ref>https://www.c-span.org/video/?478205-1/vice-president-pence-campaigns-senators-david-perdue-kelly-loeffler-canton-georgia</ref>

title: David Perdue
added: In May 2020, Perdue argued that the United States "had ordinary flu seasons with more deaths" than the COVID-19 outbreak in the country. At the time, there were over 80,000 deaths due to COVID-19 in the country, while the average over the previous 10 years was under 40,000 deaths per year for flu, with 61,000 deaths in [[2017–2018 United States flu season|2017–2018]]. As predicted by medical experts, COVID-19 is much deadlier than the flu, as the death toll in the United States rose above 240,000 within the year.<ref name="Farley"/>

title: David Perdue
added: From 2010 to 2014, Perdue served on the board of directors of the data marketing firm Cardlytics, until he joined the Senate. Perdue was legally allowed to retain Cardlytics shares until 2020 or 2022. When Cardlytics became publicly owned, Perdue profited  $6 million. An executive compensation expert told the ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' that the arrangement was "unusual and very generous", as former employees typically are allowed to retain shares for less than a year. Cardlytics stated that it had allowed the arrangement because Perdue was a "very involved and valuable board member".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mitchell |first1=Tia |title=David Perdue stock arrangement draws scrutiny |url=https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/david-perdue-stock-arrangement-draws-scrutiny/50YvSP6lzh4y98hxIftGpI/ |access-date=November 23, 2020 |work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |date=May 13, 2020}}</ref>

Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
added: The GSA administrator officially determines when an incoming presidential administration can begin to access federal agencies and [[United States presidential transition|transition funds]]. After November 7, 2020, when [[Joe Biden]] became generally acknowledged as [[president-elect of the United States|president-elect]] following the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 election]], GSA administrator [[Emily W. Murphy]] refused to sign a letter (the "ascertainment" determination) allowing Biden's transition team to begin work to facilitate an [[peaceful transition of power|orderly transition of power]].<ref name="StandsBetween" /><ref name="Rein" /> By refusing to allow the transition to proceed, she prevented the incoming administration from obtaining office space, performing background checks on prospective Cabinet nominees, and accessing classified information.<ref name="StandsBetween" /><ref name="Rein" /> Murphy's withholding of the letter also blocked Biden's transition team from accessing several million dollars in federal transition funds for salaries and other costs, establishing government email addresses, and working with the [[Office of Government Ethics]] on required financial disclosure and conflict-of-interest forms for incoming nominees.<ref name="StandsBetween" /><ref name="Rein" />

title: Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election

title: Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
added: Following the election, Trump fired the head of his [[Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency]] who contradicted Trump's claims of electoral fraud.   The Trump administration refused to initiate the presidential transition as the Trump campaigned filed lawsuits designed to overturn the results of the election.  State election officials reported being pressured to overturn the results.

title: Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
added: Days before the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]], [[Dennis L. Montgomery|Dennis Montgomery]], a software designer with a history of making dubious claims, asserted that a government supercomputer program would be used to switch votes from Trump to Biden on voting machines. Trump legal team attorney [[Sidney Powell]] promoted the conspiracy theory on ''[[Lou Dobbs Tonight]]'' on November 6,<ref>{{Cite news|date=2020-11-10|title=Fact check: TV news clip does not show 'live computerized fraud' on Election Day 2020|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-factcheck-cnn-not-evidence-vote-fraud-idUSKBN27P2TI|access-date=2020-11-15|archive-date=November 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116100851/https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-factcheck-cnn-not-evidence-vote-fraud-idUSKBN27P2TI|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last1=Fichera|first1=Angelo|last2=Spencer|first2=Saranac Hale|date=2020-11-13|title=Bogus Theory Claims Supercomputer Switched Votes in Election|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/bogus-theory-claims-supercomputer-switched-votes-in-election/|access-date=2020-11-15|website=FactCheck.org|language=en-US|archive-date=November 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115032246/https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/bogus-theory-claims-supercomputer-switched-votes-in-election/|url-status=live}}</ref> and again two days later on [[Maria Bartiromo]]'s [[Fox Business]] program, claiming to have "evidence that that is exactly what happened."<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Fichera|first1=Angelo|last2=Spencer|first2=Saranac Hale|date=2020-11-13|title=Bogus Theory Claims Supercomputer Switched Votes in Election|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/bogus-theory-claims-supercomputer-switched-votes-in-election/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-11-22|website=[[FactCheck.org]]|language=en-US}}</ref> She also asserted that the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] ignored warnings about the software, and urged Trump to fire director [[Gina Haspel]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/20/us/politics/trump-lawsuits-election.html|title=Trump's Legal Team Sets a Precedent for Lowering the Bar|first=Mark|last=Leibovich|date=November 20, 2020|work=The New York Times}}</ref> [[Christopher C. Krebs|Christopher Krebs]], director of the [[Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency]] (CISA), characterized the supercomputer claim as "nonsense" and a "hoax."<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/bogus-theory-claims-supercomputer-switched-votes-in-election/|title=Bogus Theory Claims Supercomputer Switched Votes in Election|first1=Angelo|last1=Fichera|first2=Saranac Hale|last2=Spencer|date=November 13, 2020|website=FactCheck.org|access-date=November 15, 2020|archive-date=November 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115032246/https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/bogus-theory-claims-supercomputer-switched-votes-in-election/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/top-officials-elections-most-secure-66f9361084ccbc461e3bbf42861057a5|title=Repudiating Trump, officials say election 'most secure'|date=November 13, 2020|website=AP NEWS|access-date=November 15, 2020|archive-date=November 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115030026/https://apnews.com/article/top-officials-elections-most-secure-66f9361084ccbc461e3bbf42861057a5|url-status=live}}</ref> CISA described the 2020 election as "the most secure in American history," with "no evidence that any voting system deleted or lost votes, changed votes or was in any way compromised."<ref name="auto" /><ref name="auto2" /> A few days later Trump claimed Krebs's analysis was "highly inaccurate" and Krebs was fired by tweet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/17/politics/chris-krebs-fired-by-trump/index.html|title=Trump fires director of Homeland Security agency who had rejected President's election conspiracy theories|first1=Kaitlan|last1=Collins|first2=Paul|last2=LeBlanc|website=CNN|access-date=November 18, 2020|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118003755/https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/17/politics/chris-krebs-fired-by-trump/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

During a November 19 press conference, Powell alleged without evidence that an international [[Communist]] plot had been engineered by Venezuela, Cuba, China, [[Hugo Chávez]] (who died in 2013), [[George Soros]], and the [[Clinton Foundation]], to rig the 2020 election.<ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://politi.co/3kUvpS9|title=POLITICO Playbook PM: Rudy.|first1=Jake|last1=Sherman|first2=Anna|last2=Palmer|first3=Garrett|last3=Ross|first4=Eli|last4=Okun|website=POLITICO|access-date=November 19, 2020|archive-date=November 20, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120033527/https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook-pm/2020/11/19/rudy-490945|url-status=live}}</ref> She also alleged that [[Dominion Voting Systems]] "can set and run an algorithm that probably ran all over the country to take a certain percentage of votes from President Trump and flip them to President Biden."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/19/politics/giuliani-trump-legal-team-press-briefing-fact-check/index.html|title=Fact checking Giuliani and the Trump legal team's wild, fact-free press conference|first1=Tara|last1=Subramaniam|first2=Holmes|last2=Lybrand|website=CNN|access-date=November 20, 2020|archive-date=November 20, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120015606/https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/19/politics/giuliani-trump-legal-team-press-briefing-fact-check/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref> The source for many of these claims appeared to be [[far right]] news organization [[One America News Network]] (OANN).<ref name=":8" /> She also repeated a conspiracy theory<ref>{{Cite web|last=Darcy|first=Oliver|title=Company debunks conspiracy theory that its server showed a landslide for Trump|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/17/media/scytl-debunks-conspiracy-theory/index.html|access-date=2020-11-23|website=CNN}}</ref> spread by Congressman [[Louis Gohmert|Louie Gohmert]], OANN and others:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/20/technology/trump-allies-are-among-the-frequent-purveyors-of-election-misinformation.html|title=Trump allies are among the frequent purveyors of election misinformation.|first=Linda|last=Qiu|date=November 20, 2020|work=The New York Times}}</ref> that accurate voting results had been transmitted to the German office of the Spanish [[electronic voting]] firm [[Scytl]], where they were tabulated to reveal a landslide victory for Trump, after which a company server was supposedly seized in a raid by the United States Army.<ref name=":8" /> The US Army and Scytl refuted these claims:<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Joffe-Block|first1=Jude|url=https://apnews.com/article/fact-checking-afs:Content:9754011363|title=False reports claim election servers were seized in Germany|date=November 14, 2020|work=[[Associated Press|AP News]]|access-date=November 22, 2020|archive-date=November 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115091412/https://apnews.com/article/fact-checking-afs:Content:9754011363|url-status=live}}</ref> Scytl has not had any offices in Germany since September 2019, and does not tabulate US votes.<ref name="scytl-pr-13-nov">{{cite web |title=Scytl strongly denies the false information related to the U.S. elections |url=https://www.scytl.com/en/fact-checking-regarding-us-elections-debunking-fake-news/ |website=Scytl |accessdate=21 November 2020 |date=13 November 2020 |archive-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120201610/https://www.scytl.com/en/fact-checking-regarding-us-elections-debunking-fake-news/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="nyt-scytl">{{cite web |last1=Roose |first1=Kevin |title=No, the Army didn't seize a German server showing a Trump landslide |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/18/technology/scytl-trump.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=21 November 2020 |date=18 November 2020 |archive-date=November 21, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121025922/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/18/technology/scytl-trump.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

In a subsequent interview with [[Newsmax]] on November 21,<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-11-22|title=Trump lawyer Sidney Powell says Georgia election lawsuit "will be biblical," suggests GOP governor helped Biden|url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-lawyer-sidney-powell-says-georgia-election-lawsuit-will-biblical-suggests-gop-governor-1549333|access-date=2020-11-23|website=Newsweek|language=en}}</ref> Powell accused [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia's]] Republican governor, [[Brian Kemp]], of being "in on the Dominion scam" and suggested financial impropriety.<ref>{{Cite web|agency=Associated Press|date=2020-11-23|title=Trump campaign cuts ties with attorney Sidney Powell after bizarre election fraud claims|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/23/trump-campaign-cuts-ties-with-attorney-sidney-powell-after-bizarre-election-claims|access-date=2020-11-23|website=the Guardian|language=en}}</ref> Powell additionally alleged that fraud had cost [[Doug Collins (politician)|Doug Collins]] the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] against incumbent [[Kelly Loeffler]] in the [[2020–21 United States Senate special election in Georgia|Senate race in Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Haberman |first1=Maggie |last2=Feuer |first2=Alan |title=Trump Team Disavows Lawyer Who Peddled Conspiracy Theories on Voting |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/22/us/politics/sidney-powell-trump.html |access-date=November 26, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://archive.ph/5fSxF |archive-date=November 23, 2020}}</ref> She also claimed the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] had used rigged Dominion machines to defeat [[Bernie Sanders]] in the 2016 primary, and that Sanders learned of this but "sold out."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/election-2020/trump-lawyer-sidney-powell-accuses-georgia-gov-brian-kemp-and-bernie-sanders-of-complicity-in-bonkers-voting-machine-conspiracy/|title=Sidney Powell Goes After Brian Kemp Over Election Conspiracy|date=November 22, 2020|publisher=Mediaite|access-date=November 22, 2020|archive-date=November 22, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201122191809/https://www.mediaite.com/election-2020/trump-lawyer-sidney-powell-accuses-georgia-gov-brian-kemp-and-bernie-sanders-of-complicity-in-bonkers-voting-machine-conspiracy/|url-status=live}}</ref> She stated she would "blow up" Georgia with a "biblical" court filing.<ref>{{Cite news|date=2020-11-23|title=Sidney Powell: Trump team cuts ties with lawyer who peddled bizarre fraud claims|language=en-GB|work=[[BBC News]]|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/election-us-2020-55040756|access-date=2020-11-24}}</ref> Powell suggested that candidates "paid to have the system rigged to work for them."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Vella|first=Lauren|date=November 19, 2020|title=Ernst: Trump lawyer claim that candidates pay to rig elections 'absolutely outrageous'|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/526798-ernst-trump-lawyer-claim-that-candidates-pay-to-rig-elections-absolutely|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120033548/https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/526798-ernst-trump-lawyer-claim-that-candidates-pay-to-rig-elections-absolutely|archive-date=November 20, 2020|access-date=November 20, 2020|website=The Hill}}</ref> On the basis of these claims, Powell called for Republican-controlled [[State legislature (United States)|state legislatures]] in swing states to disregard the election results and appoint a [[Slate (elections)|slate]] of "loyal" [[United States Electoral College#Electors|electors]] who would vote to re-elect President Trump,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Smith|first=David|date=2020-11-21|title=Trump makes futile last stand to overturn results as Georgia certifies Biden win|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/20/trump-michigan-republicans-election|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121060545/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/20/trump-michigan-republicans-election|archive-date=November 21, 2020|access-date=2020-11-21|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en}}</ref> based on authority supposedly resting in [[Article Two of the United States Constitution#Clause 2: Method of choosing electors|Article Two of the Constitution]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/JasonSCampbell/status/1329549873516048387 |title=Sidney Powell: "The entire election, frankly, in all the swing states should be overturned and the legislatures should make sure that the electors are selected for Trump" |access-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120033548/https://twitter.com/JasonSCampbell/status/1329549873516048387 |url-status=live }}</ref>

title: Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
added: In October 2020 Trump signed an executive order that created a new category of federal employees, [[Schedule F appointment|Schedule F]], which included all career civil servants whose job includes "policymaking". Such employees would no longer be covered by [[United States federal civil service|civil service]] protections against arbitrary dismissal, but would be subject to the same rules as political appointees. The new description could be applied to thousands of nonpartisan experts such as scientists, who give advice to the the political appointees who run their departments.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/trump-executive-order-civil-service-biden-election-schedule-f-b1255692.html|title=Trump just quietly passed an executive order that could destroy a future Biden administration|last=Feinberg|first=Andrew|date=October 30, 2020|work=The Independent|accessdate=1 December 2020}}</ref> Heads of all federal agencies were ordered to report by January 29, 2021 a list of positions that could be reclassified as Schedule F. The [[Office of Management and Budget]] submitted a list in November that included 88 percent of the office's workforce.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2020/11/21/omb_lists_workers_stripped_of_job_protection_under_trump_order_144708.html|title=OMB Lists Positions Stripped of Job Protection Under Trump Order .|last=Wegmann|first=Philip|date=November 21, 2020|work=Real Clear Politics|accessdate=1 December 2020}}</ref> Federal employee organizations and Congressional Democrats sought to overturn the order via lawsuits or bills. House Democrats warned in a letter that "The executive order could precipitate a mass exodus from the federal government at the end of every presidential administration, leaving federal agencies without deep institutional knowledge, expertise, experience, and the ability to develop and implement long-term policy strategies."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2020/11/congress-employee-groups-ramp-up-pressure-to-block-schedule-f-executive-order/|title=Congress, employee groups ramp up pressure to block Schedule F executive order|last=Ogrysko|first=Nicole|date=November 24, 2020|work=Federal News Network|accessdate=1 December 2020}}</ref> Observers predicted that Trump could use the new rule to implement a "massive government purge on his way out the door."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/trump-lays-the-groundwork-for-a-massive-government-purge-on-his-way-out-the-door/2020/11/30/280519ac-333d-11eb-a997-1f4c53d2a747_story.html|title=Trump lays the groundwork for a massive government purge on his way out the door|last=Rampell|first=Catherine|date=November 30, 2020|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=1 December 2020}}</ref>

Scott Gottlieb
added: On March 29, 2020, Gottlieb and several public health experts published "​National Coronavirus Response: A Road Map to Reopening" providing specific actions for navigating through the current [[COVID-19 pandemic]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | title=National coronavirus response: A road map to reopening |url=https://www.aei.org/research-products/report/national-coronavirus-response-a-road-map-to-reopening/|website= AEI|accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref>  Since April 2020, Gottlieb has advised several governors on the [[COVID-19 pandemic]]. He joined [[Governor of Maryland|Maryland Governor]] [[Larry Hogan]]'s [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] response team and [[Governor of Massachusetts|Massachusetts Governor]] [[Charlie Baker]]'s [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] Advisory Board.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2020/04/07/scoop-trumps-shadow-coronavirus-czar-will-now-advise-larry-hogan-488823|title=POLITICO Playbook: Scoop: Trump's 'shadow coronavirus czar' will now advise Larry Hogan|last1=Sherman|first1=Jake|last2=Palmer|first2=Anna|website=POLITICO|language=en|access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref> He has also advised [[Governor of Connecticut|Connecticut Governor]] [[Ned Lamont]] as a member of the Reopen Connecticut Advisory Group.<ref>{{cite web | title=Governor Lamont Announces Creation of Group of Health and Business Experts Who Will Provide Advice and Recommendations on the Reopening of Connecticut’s Economy |url=https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/04-2020/Governor-Lamont-Announces-Creation-of-Group-of-Health-and-Business-Experts|website= portal.ct.gov|accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> It was announced on November 20 that Gottlieb will serve on Montana's Governor-elect Greg Gianforte’s [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] task force.<ref>{{cite web | title=Former FDA head named to Montana COVID-19 panel|url=https://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2020/11/20/former-fda-commissioner-named-montana-covid-19-panel/6362467002/|website= greatfallstribune|accessdate=November 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Matt Ridley
added: Ridley wrote a 2017 column making the case for free-market anticapitalism. He writes, "'Capitalism' and 'markets' mean the same thing to most people. And that is very misleading. Commerce, enterprise and markets are – to me – the very opposite of corporatism and even of 'capitalism', if by that word you mean capital-intensive organisations with monopolistic ambitions."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://capx.co/the-case-for-free-market-anticapitalism/|title=The case for free-market anticapitalism|date=July 12, 2017|accessdate=November 23, 2020|work=CapX}}</ref>

title: Gavin Newsom
deleted: An effort to recall Governor Newsom began early 2020, led by the California Patriot Coalition, and has gathered about 800,000 petition signatures, over half of the required number needed to qualify the recall for an election. The effort has been granted an extension until March 17th, 2021 to collect a total of nearly 1,500,000 signatures.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Marinucci|first=Carla|title=French Laundry snafu reignites longshot Newsom recall drive|url=https://politi.co/3nOImia|access-date=2020-12-03|website=Politico PRO|language=en}}</ref><ref>https://recallgavin2020.com/</ref>

title: 2020 Massachusetts elections
added: Several measures were not certified to circulate because they went against Massachusetts law on ballot measures. Others were cleared for circulation but did not collect enough initial signatures for the December 4, 2019 deadline<ref>{{Cite web|title=Current petitions filed|url=https://www.mass.gov/info-details/current-petitions-filed|access-date=2020-04-28|website=Mass.gov|language=en}}</ref>

Despite reaching a sufficient number of signatures in the first round, supporters of two measures (19-11 and 19-14) failed to collect the necessary number of signatures in the second round. By early July both initiatives had "effectively dropped their 2020 efforts".<ref name="NikJuly2">{{cite news|last=DeCosta-Klipa|first=Nik|date=July 2, 2020|title=Two proposed Massachusetts ballot questions bite the dust amid pandemic|website=[[Boston.com]]|url=https://www.boston.com/news/politics/2020/07/02/massachusetts-ballot-questions-2020-dropped-amid-pandemic|accessdate=July 2, 2020}}</ref>

title: Collin Peterson
deleted: Peterson had long fended off various Republican challengers during his tenure in Congress, but his district had grown increasingly more conservative during that timeframe. As the national Democratic Party had moved far to Peterson's left on social issues, his constituents became even less interested in the party; for example, Peterson had outrun the Democratic presidential nominee in each election since 2000 (the Republican candidate had won his district each time, often with widening margins except [[Barack Obama]] in 2008, who only lost 50-47).

However, the rise of [[Donald Trump]]'s presidential bid, his presidency, and his intense popularity in rural America had led Peterson to become more vulnerable as Trump concurrently fueled rural ire against the Democratic Party, including the DFL. As a result of this, Peterson would finally be defeated by a Republican, [[Michelle Fischbach]], in the [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Minnesota#District 7|2020 election]].

added: == Second Gentleman of the United States ==

Following the election of [[Joe Biden]] as the 46th President of the United States in November 2020, Emhoff is expected to become the first Second Gentleman of the United States in January 2021 as he is the spouse of [[President-elect of the United States|Vice President-elect]] [[Kamala Harris]].

title: Jennifer Wexton
added: Wexton supports strengthening the [[Affordable Care Act]] and opposes the Trump administration's efforts to convince the US Supreme Court to invalidate the law. In a 2020 debate, she argued that striking down the ACA would once again allow insurance companies to impose lifetime health care spending limits.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|last=Olivo|first=Antonio|title=Jennifer Wexton, Aliscia Andrews spar over immigration, health care during debate in blue-leaning Virginia congressional district|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/wexton-andrews-congressional-race-debate/2020/10/15/1f53efbe-0ca9-11eb-8a35-237ef1eb2ef7_story.html|access-date=2020-11-28|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
Wexton supports expanding the federal [[Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program|seasonal agricultural worker visa program]] and the [[H-1B visa]] program.<ref name=":4" />

Wexton supports making it easier for workers to unionize. She criticized the Trump administration for not enforcing federally mandated workplace protections during the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|coronavirus pandemic]].<ref name=":4" />

Robert Garcia (California congressman)
added: Garcia fostered the first citywide Project Labor Agreement (PLA) between the City of Long Beach, the Los Angeles/Orange Counties Building and the Construction Trades Council to promote opportunities for local-hire on local-capital construction projects. Since its approval and implementation, 25 construction projects, valued at more than $146 million have been built by a local labor workforce.<ref>http://laocbuildingtrades.org/trades-win-in-long-beach/</ref><ref>http://www.longbeach.gov/finance/business-info/compliance/project-labor-agreement/</ref>

Mayor Garcia also supported the unionization of cannabis and hotel workers, the organization of dock and port laborers, and has fought against attempts in the city to contract work outside of the community.<ref>https://www.presstelegram.com/2018/06/19/long-beach-will-soon-allow-recreational-marijuana-sales-after-city-council-votes-in-favor-of-regulating-industry/</ref> The mayor is proud to have long marched beside organized labor to increase workers’ minimum wage – before the California State Legislature took action – and most recently to pass the city’s first recall and retention plan in response to workers laid off due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Robert Garcia (California congressman)
deleted: Garcia was the California Youth Coordinator for the [[George W. Bush 2000 presidential campaign]]<ref name="repub_ocregister">{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Joshua|title=Ambassador vs. CEO: Long Beach mayoral candidates have different approaches|newspaper=[[Orange County Register]]|location=Orange County, California|date=April 25, 2014|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/city-611453-mayor-council.html|accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref><ref name="repub_presstelegram">{{cite news|last=Bradley|first=Eric|title=2014 Long Beach mayoral race: Robert Garcia focused on growth|newspaper=[[Press-Telegram]]|location=[[Long Beach, California]]|date=March 26, 2014|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/20140326/2014-long-beach-mayoral-race-robert-garcia-focused-on-growth|accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Modesti|first=Kevin|title=Long Beach Mayor’s rising political star raises questions and, for some, hope|newspaper=[[Press-Telegram]]|location=[[Long Beach, California]]|date=August 9, 2019|url=https://www.presstelegram.com/2019/08/09/long-beach-mayors-rising-political-star-raises-questions-and-for-some-hope/|accessdate=October 14, 2019}}</ref> He also founded the Long Beach Young Republicans in 2005. Describing himself as socially liberal and fiscally conservative, Garcia guided and organized the Young Republicans, which developed a charter that was recognized as an official club by the Los Angeles County Republicans. <ref>{{cite news|last=O'Carroll|first=Marianna|title=New Young Republican chapter arrives|newspaper=CSULB Online 49er|location=[[Long Beach, California]]|date=September 21, 2005|url=http://web.csulb.edu/~d49er/archives/2005/fall/news/volLVno147-republican.shtml|accessdate=November 6, 2020}}</ref> Garcia also worked as an aide to Frank Colonna when he was on City Council and ran Colonna's unsuccessful bid in the [[2006 Long Beach, California mayoral election]]. <ref>{{cite news|last= Wride |first=Nancy|title= Vice Mayor Announces Run for Long Beach Mayor |newspaper= Patch |location=[[Long Beach, California]]|date= July 17, 2013 |url= https://patch.com/california/belmontshore/vice-mayor-announces-run-for-long-beach-mayor |accessdate=November 9, 2020}}</ref>

title: Robert Garcia (California congressman)
added: In July 2020 and inspired by the [[George Floyd protests]], a petition to recall Mayor Garcia was approved by the Long Beach City Clerk. Activists cited Garcia’s "immoral leadership" and financial support from the Long Beach Police Officers Association, the union that represents local police.<ref>{{cite web |title=Backers of mayor recall can begin gathering signatures |url=https://lbpost.com/news/backers-of-mayor-recall-can-begin-gathering-signatures |website=Long Beach Post |accessdate=18 August 2020 |date=23 July 2020}}</ref> On November 9, 2020, the mayoral recall was canceled in the wake of the national election. Activist Franklin Sims claimed he and his supporters were being intimidated.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mayoral recall called off in wake of presidential election results, claims of intimidation |url=https://lbpost.com/news/mayoral-recall-called-off-in-wake-of-presidential-election-results-claims-of-intimidation |website=Long Beach Post |accessdate=11 November 2020 |date=9 November 2020}}</ref>

title: Cabinet of Joe Biden
added: Cabinet-level officials have positions that are considered to be of Cabinet level, but which are not part of the Cabinet.  Which exact positions ''are'' considered part of the presidential cabinet, can vary with the president.  The [[Director of Central Intelligence|CIA]] and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]] were cabinet-level agencies under [[Bill Clinton]], but not [[George W. Bush]].  The head of the [[Office of National Drug Control Policy]] (aka the [[List of U.S. executive branch czars|drug czar]]) was a cabinet-level position under both Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, but not under [[Barack Obama]]. (Not to be confused with the head of the [[United States Drug Enforcement Agency|DEA]], who has remained in the [[org chart]] underneath the cabinet position held by the [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]].)  Designation of an agency as being cabinet-level requires{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} that [[Act of Congress#Promulgation (United States)|Congress enact legislation]], although [[executive order]]s unilaterally created by the president can be used to create many other types of position inside the [[executive branch]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}  Members of the cabinet proper, as well as cabinet-level officials, meet with the president in [[Cabinet Room (White House)|a room adjacent to the Oval Office]].

The [[White House Chief of Staff]] has traditionally been the highest-ranking employee of the [[White House Office|White House]]. The responsibilities of the chief of staff are both managerial and advisory over the president's official business. The chief of staff is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the [[president of the United States|president]]; it does not require [[Advice and consent|Senate confirmation]].

On November 11, 2020, Biden announced that [[Ron Klain]] would assume the position upon his inauguration.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/klain-biden-white-house/2020/11/11/3c64069a-21d3-11eb-a688-5298ad5d580a_story.html |title=Biden’s choice of Ron Klain to run White House signals rejection of Trump-era chaos |last1=Schrer |first1=Michael |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 11, 2020 |accessdate=November 11, 2020 }}</ref>

title: John Hickenlooper
deleted: {{main|2020 United States Senate election in Colorado}}

In a YouTube video published to his campaign channel on August 22, 2019, Hickenlooper announced that he would run for the [[United States Senate]] in [[2020 United States Senate election in Colorado|2020]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hickenlooper |first1=John |title=Not Done Fighting |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-63689Ahyuk |date=August 22, 2019 |website=YouTube |publisher=John Hickenlooper |accessdate=22 August 2019}}</ref> Some preliminary polling data showed him with a substantial lead against incumbent Republican [[Cory Gardner|U.S. Senator Cory Gardner]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msnbc.com/11th-hour/watch/john-hickenlooper-expected-to-end-his-2020-campaign-may-shift-to-senate-run-66137157827 |date=August 15, 2019 |title=John Hickenlooper expected to end his 2020 campaign, may shift to Senate run|website=MSNBC.com}}</ref> Hickenlooper was also leading the Democratic primary field by a fairly wide margin before he announced.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wingerter |first1=Justin |title=Hickenlooper would have a massive lead in Senate primary, poll finds |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2019/08/12/john-hickenlooper-2020-senate-cory-gardner/ |website=The Denver Post |accessdate=22 August 2019}}</ref> He was quickly endorsed by the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]], a move protested by candidates already running before Hickenlooper's entry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/six-women-seeking-colorado-senate-seat-ask-dscc-to-reconsider-endorsement-of-hickenlooper/2019/08/27/89feff52-c8e4-11e9-a1fe-ca46e8d573c0_story.html|title=Six women seeking Colorado Senate seat ask DSCC to reconsider endorsement of Hickenlooper|website=The Washington Post | accessdate=15 September 2019}}</ref>

On June 30, Hickenlooper defeated former state house Speaker [[Andrew Romanoff]] in the Democratic primary,<ref>{{Cite news|title=Live: Colorado State Primary Election Results 2020|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/06/30/us/elections/results-colorado-primary-elections.html|access-date=2020-07-01|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> winning the nomination to challenge one-term incumbent Republican [[Cory Gardner]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cpr.org/2020/06/30/hickenlooper-wins-the-dem-senate-primary-will-face-cory-gardner/|title=Hickenlooper Wins The Dem Senate Primary; Will Face Cory Gardner|website=CPR News | accessdate=30 June 2020}}</ref> Hickenlooper defeated Gardner.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Alas |first1=Horus |title=Democrat John Hickenlooper Defeats Cory Gardner for Colorado Senate Seat |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-11-03/democrat-john-hickenlooper-defeats-cory-gardner-for-colorado-senate-seat |work=U.S. News |date=November 3, 2020}}</ref>

title: Doug Mastriano
deleted: Mastriano had been criticized{{By whom|date=November 2020}} for posts on his campaign's Facebook page, "Doug Mastriano Fighting for Freedom", which draws heavily from right-wing social media and web publications.

In May 2019, during his campaign for state senate, Mastriano was accused of spreading Islamophobia after sharing several posts on his campaign Facebook page targeting Muslims. "Islam wants to kill gay rights, Judaism, Christianity and pacifism" read one of the posts, which critiqued the common "Coexist" bumper stickers.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hullinger|first=Logan|title=GOP candidate for Alloway's state Senate seat accused of spreading Islamophobia|url=https://www.yorkdispatch.com/story/news/politics/2019/05/07/gop-candidate-alloways-state-senate-seat-accused-spreading-islamophobia/3661917002/|access-date=2020-10-15|website=York Dispatch|language=en-US}}</ref> After the [[Notre-Dame de Paris fire|Notre Dame fire]] Mastriano had shared an image that was circulated in the wake of the fire suggesting that it had been an act by Muslim terrorists.<ref>🖉{{Cite web|url=https://www.penncapital-star.com/government-politics/conspiratorial-anti-muslim-memes-populate-facebook-page-of-state-senate-candidate/|title=Conspiratorial, anti-Muslim memes populated Facebook page of state Senate candidate|date=May 6, 2019}}</ref> In April 2018, his campaign Facebook page shared an article headlined, “A Dangerous Trend: Muslims running for office.”<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hardison|first=Elizabeth|date=2019-05-06|title=Conspiratorial, anti-Muslim memes populated Facebook page of state Senate candidate|url=https://www.penncapital-star.com/government-politics/conspiratorial-anti-muslim-memes-populate-facebook-page-of-state-senate-candidate/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-10-15|website=Pennsylvania Capital-Star|language=en-US}}</ref>

While various Democratic critics condemned his Facebook posts, neither Mastriano, the county, nor the state Republican party responded publicly about the issue.<ref name="phobia">{{cite web|last=Hullinger|first=Logan|title=GOP candidate for Alloway's state Senate seat accused of spreading Islamophobia|url=https://www.yorkdispatch.com/story/news/politics/2019/05/07/gop-candidate-alloways-state-senate-seat-accused-spreading-islamophobia/3661917002/|access-date=May 7, 2019|website=York Dispatch|language=en}}</ref>

After Mastriano's election to state senate, the auditor of [[Reading Township, Adams County, Pennsylvania|Reading Township]], located [[Adams County, Pennsylvania|Adams County]] in Mastriano's district, wrote a letter in ''[[The Gettysburg Times]]'' in which he criticized Mastriano with claims such as "Doug's page is active at seemingly every hour of the day", and "Whether it is Doug himself or a staffer running the page, does the Mastriano team not have anything better to do? Why is a full-time elected official spending so much of their time on social media interacting with people they don't represent?" Mastriano did not respond to the auditor's criticism.<ref>{{Cite newspaper|date=August 20, 2019|title=Mastriano should leave Facebook|language=en|newspaper=[[The Gettysburg Times]]|url=http://www.gettysburgtimes.com/opinion/letters_to_editor/article_1630f347-de41-5dc9-84b1-2de0aa5cb779.html|url-access=subscription|access-date=August 21, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Senator Doug Mastriano|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/category/Government-Official/SenatorDougMastriano/videos/|access-date=2020-10-15|website=facebook.com|language=en}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States elections
deleted: Both of Georgia's 2020 Senate races, a regular election and a special election, advanced to a January runoff:<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/06/2020-georgia-runoff-election-senate-loeffler-ossoff/6192322002/|title=Georgia runoff elections will determine control of US Senate: How we got here|first=Josh|last=Peter|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 6, 2020|accessdate=November 8, 2020}}</ref>

* [[2020 United States Senate election in Georgia|Georgia Class 2]]: A regular election for the seat was held on November 3, 2020, concurrently with the U.S. Senate special election per Georgia law. The incumbent is [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[David Perdue]], who was elected in [[2014 United States Senate election in Georgia|2014]] and is running for a second term in the [[Classes of United States senators|Class II]] seat. Perdue was unopposed in the Republican primary. The [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee is [[Jon Ossoff]],<ref>{{citation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200916193232/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/09/16/senate-seats-most-likely-flip-november/ |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/09/16/senate-seats-most-likely-flip-november/ |archivedate= September 16, 2020 |work= [[Washingtonpost.com]] |title=The Senate seats most likely to flip in November |author= Amber Phillips |date= September 16, 2020 }}</ref> a media executive and the Democratic nominee for [[Georgia's 6th congressional district]] in a [[2017 Georgia's 6th congressional district special election|2017 special election]]. Because neither Perdue nor Ossoff attained the 50% winning threshold, they advanced to the runoff election scheduled for January 5, 2021.<ref name=vox>{{cite news |author1=Jerusalem Demsas |author2=Ella Nilsen |title=David Perdue and Jon Ossoff advanced to Georgia Senate runoff |url=https://www.vox.com/2020/11/5/21537684/senate-results-georgia-perdue-jon-ossoff-runoff |accessdate=November 6, 2020 |work=Vox |date=November 5, 2020}}</ref>

* [[2020 United States Senate special election in Georgia|Georgia Class 3]]: [[Governor of Georgia|Governor]] [[Brian Kemp]] appointed Republican incumbent [[Kelly Loeffler]] to succeed [[Johnny Isakson]] effective January 6, 2020, after his resignation took effect on December 31, 2019.<ref name="Isakson">{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/08/28/politics/johnny-isakson-retire/index.html |title=Georgia Republican Sen. Johnny Isakson to resign at end of year |last=Rogers|first=Alex|last2=Bradner |first2=Eric |last3=Mattingly |first3=Phil |publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. |date=August 28, 2019 |website=CNN.com|access-date=November 6, 2020}}</ref> Also per Georgia law, a special election took place on the same day as the Senate regular election for the other seat held by David Purdue. A [[primary election]] did not occur; instead, all candidates, regardless of party, were placed on the same ballot. Party labels were printed on the ballot and as neither Loeffler nor her Democratic challenger [[Raphael Warnock]] received more than 50% of the vote, the top two finishers also advanced to the special runoff election, to be held also on January 5, 2021.{{r|vox}}

title: Political parties in the United States
Political parties in the United States
added: {{short description|Political parties in the United States}}
{{For|a complete list|List of political parties in the United States}}

American electoral politics has been dominated by two major [[political parties]] since shortly after the founding of the republic. Since the 1850s, they have been the [[History of the United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party ]] and the [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. Since the last major party realignment in the mid-20th century, the Democratic Party has been the [[center-left]] and [[Modern Liberalism in the United States|liberal]] party, and the Republican Party has been the [[center-right]] and [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] party. Since the 1990s both the Republican and Democratic parties have shifted further apart. This [[two-party system]] is based on laws, party rules and custom, not specifically outlined in the US Constitution. Several [[Third party (United States)|third parties]] also operate in the U.S., and from time to time elect someone to local office.<ref>William B. Hesseltine, ''Third-Party Movements in the United States'' (1962)</ref> The largest third party since the 1980s has been the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]].

Besides the [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution]], [[Green Party of the United States|Green]], and [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] parties, there are [[List of political parties in the United States|many other political parties]] that receive only minimal support and only appear on the ballot in one or a few states.

The need to win popular support in a [[Republicanism in the United States|republic]] led to the American invention of voter-based political parties in the 1790s.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Roy Franklin Nichols |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=34g0AAAAIAAJ |title=The invention of the American political parties |publisher=Macmillan |year=1967 |access-date=2015-10-31 |archive-date=2016-06-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617132710/https://books.google.com/books?id=34g0AAAAIAAJ |url-status=live }}</ref> Americans were especially innovative in devising new campaign techniques that linked public opinion with public policy through the party.<ref>Robert J. Dinkin,  ''Campaigning in America: A History of Election Practices.'' [https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=14291969 (Greenwood 1989) online version] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420055859/http://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o |date=2010-04-20 }}</ref>

Political scientists and historians have divided the development of America's two-party system into five eras.<ref>Paul Kleppner, et al. ''The Evolution of American Electoral Systems'' (1983),</ref> The first two-party system consisted of the [[Federalist Party]], which supported the ratification of the Constitution, and the [[Democratic-Republican Party]] or the [[Anti-Administration party]] (Anti-Federalists), which opposed the powerful central government that the Constitution established when it took effect in 1789.<ref>{{Cite web |date=May 26, 2016 |title=The First Political Parties: Federalists and Anti-Federalists |url=https://www.boundless.com/political-science/textbooks/boundless-political-science-textbook/interest-groups-7/the-history-of-political-parties-55/the-first-political-parties-federalists-and-anti-federalists-316-1572/ |access-date=July 27, 2016 |website=Boundless Political Science |publisher=Boundless.com |archive-date=October 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013034743/https://www.boundless.com/political-science/textbooks/boundless-political-science-textbook/interest-groups-7/the-history-of-political-parties-55/the-first-political-parties-federalists-and-anti-federalists-316-1572/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Party realignments have recurred periodically in response to social and cultural movements and economic development.

The modern two-party system consists of the "Democratic" Party and the "Republican" Party. However these names, while they have been in existence since before the Civil War, have not always represented the same ideology or electorate. These two parties have won every [[United States presidential election]] since [[1852 United States presidential election|1852]] and have controlled the [[United States Congress]] [[Divided government in the United States|since at least 1856]].<ref>Byron E. Shafer and Anthony J. Badger, eds. ''Contesting Democracy: Substance and Structure in American Political History, 1775–2000'' (2001)/</ref>

Some political candidates, and many voters, choose not to identify with a particular political party. In some states, [[Independent voter#In the United States|independents]] are not allowed to vote in [[primary election|primary elections]], but in others, they can vote in any primary election of their choice. Although the term "independent" often is used as a synonym for "moderate," "centrist," or "[[swing voter]]," to refer to a politician or voter who holds views that incorporate facets of both liberal and conservative ideologies, most self-described independents consistently support one of the two major parties when it comes time to vote, according to [[Vox Media]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Klar |first=Samara |date=2016-01-22 |title=9 media myths about independent voters, debunked |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/1/22/10814522/independents-voters-facts-myths |access-date=2019-03-07 |website=Vox |archive-date=2019-09-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190905002236/https://www.vox.com/2016/1/22/10814522/independents-voters-facts-myths |url-status=live }}</ref>

title: Stuxnet
added: |quote  = "[O]ne of the great technical blockbusters in malware history".

Unlike most malware, Stuxnet does little harm to computers and networks that do not meet specific configuration requirements; "The attackers took great care to make sure that only their designated targets were hit... It was a marksman's job."{{r|broad20110115}} While the worm is promiscuous, it makes itself inert if Siemens software is not found on infected computers, and contains safeguards to prevent each infected computer from spreading the worm to more than three others, and to erase itself on 24 June 2012.{{r|gross201104}}

For its targets, Stuxnet contains, among other things, code for a [[man-in-the-middle attack]] that fakes industrial process control sensor signals so an infected system does not shut down due to detected abnormal behavior.{{r|gross201104}}{{r|broad20110115}}<ref name=SonsOfStuxnet>{{cite magazine|author1=Steven Cherry |author2=with Larry Constantine |title=Sons of Stuxnet|url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/podcast/telecom/security/sons-of-stuxnet|magazine=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=14 December 2011}}</ref> Such complexity is very unusual for [[malware]]. The worm consists of a layered attack against three different systems:
# Siemens PCS 7, WinCC and STEP7 industrial software applications that run on Windows and
# One or more Siemens S7 PLCs.

Stuxnet attacked Windows systems using an unprecedented four [[Zero-day (computing)|zero-day]] attacks (plus the [[CPLINK]] [[vulnerability (computing)|vulnerability]] and a vulnerability used by the [[Conficker]] worm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/dd452420.aspx|title=Conficker Worm: Help Protect Windows from Conficker|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|date=10 April 2009|access-date=6 December 2010}}</ref>). It is initially spread using infected removable drives such as [[USB flash drive]]s,<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /><ref name="eset_microscope" /> which contain Windows shortcut files to initiate executable code.<ref>{{cite web|last=Buda|first=Alex|title=Creating Malware using the Stuxnet LNK Exploit |url=http://www.rubydevices.com.au/blog/stuxnetLnkExploit|publisher=Ruby Devices|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> The worm then uses other exploits and techniques such as [[peer-to-peer]] [[remote procedure call]] (RPC) to infect and update other computers inside private networks that are not directly connected to the Internet.<ref name=wired /><ref>{{cite web|author=Liam O Murchu|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-p2p-component|title=Stuxnet P2P component|publisher=[[NortonLifeLock|Symantec]]|date=17 September 2010|access-date=24 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="symantec_dossier" /> The number of zero-day exploits used is unusual, as they are highly valued and [[Hacker (computer security)|malware creators]] do not typically make use of (and thus simultaneously make visible) four different zero-day exploits in the same worm.<ref name=BBC /> Amongst these exploits were remote code execution on a computer with Printer Sharing enabled,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-061 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-061.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> and the LNK/PIF vulnerability,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-046 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-046.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=2 August 2010}}</ref> in which file execution is accomplished when an icon is viewed in Windows Explorer, negating the need for user interaction.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alexander|last=Gostev|title=Myrtus and Guava, Episode MS10-061|url=https://securelist.com/blog/incidents/29747/myrtus-and-guava-episode-ms10-061/|publisher=[[Kaspersky Lab]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> Stuxnet is unusually large at half a megabyte in size,<ref name=wired>{{cite magazine|author=Kim Zetter |title=Blockbuster Worm Aimed for Infrastructure, But No Proof Iran Nukes Were Target|url=https://www.wired.com/2010/09/stuxnet-2/|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=23 September 2010 |access-date=4 November 2016}}</ref> and written in several different programming languages (including [[C (programming language)|C]] and [[C++]]) which is also irregular for malware.<ref name=compworld /><ref name="Keizer1" /><ref name=SonsOfStuxnet /> The Windows component of the malware is [[promiscuous]] in that it spreads relatively quickly and indiscriminately.<ref name="eset_microscope" />

The malware has both [[Protection ring|user mode and kernel mode]] [[rootkit]] ability under Windows,<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> and its [[device driver]]s have been [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the private keys of two [[public key certificate]]s that were stolen from separate well-known companies, [[JMicron]] and [[Realtek]], both located at [[Hsinchu Science Park]] in Taiwan.<ref name="eset_microscope" /><ref name=wired /> The [[Code signing|driver signing]] helped it install [[Protection ring|kernel mode]] rootkit drivers successfully without users being notified, and thus it remained undetected for a relatively long period of time.<ref name=kaspersky>{{cite web |url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2010/Kaspersky_Lab_provides_its_insights_on_Stuxnet_worm |title=Kaspersky Lab provides its insights on Stuxnet worm |publisher=Kaspersky Lab |date=24 September 2010 |access-date=27 September 2010}}</ref> Both compromised certificates have been [[Revocation list|revoked]] by [[Verisign]].

Two websites in Denmark and Malaysia were configured as [[command and control]] servers for the malware, allowing it to be updated, and for [[industrial espionage]] to be conducted by uploading information. Both of these [[domain name]]s have subsequently been redirected by their [[DNS]] service provider to [[Dynadot]] as part of a global effort to disable the malware.<ref name="symantec_dossier" />{{r|gross201104}}
According to researcher Ralph Langner,<ref>{{cite journal
}}</ref> once installed on a Windows system Stuxnet infects project files belonging to Siemens' [[WinCC]]/[[PCS 7]] SCADA control software<ref>{{cite web

}} (Step 7), and subverts a key communication library of WinCC called s7otbxdx.dll. Doing so intercepts communications between the WinCC software running under Windows and the target Siemens PLC devices that the software is able to configure and program when the two are connected via a data cable. In this way, the malware is able to install itself on PLC devices unnoticed, and subsequently to mask its presence from WinCC if the control software attempts to read an infected block of memory from the PLC system.

The malware furthermore used a [[Zero-day (computing)|zero-day exploit]] in the WinCC/SCADA database software in the form of a hard-coded database password.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-2772|title=Vulnerability Summary for CVE-2010-2772|date=22 July 2010|access-date=7 December 2010|publisher=[[National Vulnerability Database]]}}</ref>
The entirety of the Stuxnet code has not yet been disclosed, but its payload targets only those SCADA configurations that meet criteria that it is programmed to identify.{{r|gross201104}}

Stuxnet requires specific slave [[variable-frequency drive]]s (frequency converter drives) to be attached to the targeted Siemens S7-300 system and its associated modules. It only attacks those PLC systems with variable-frequency drives from two specific vendors: [[Vacon]] based in Finland and Fararo Paya based in Iran.<ref name="chien">{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-breakthrough|title=Stuxnet: A Breakthrough|author=Eric Chien|publisher=Symantec|date=12 November 2010|access-date=14 November 2010}}</ref> Furthermore, it monitors the frequency of the attached motors, and only attacks systems that spin between 807 [[Hertz|Hz]] and 1,210 Hz. This is a much higher frequency than motors operate in most industrial applications, with the notable exception of  [[gas centrifuge]]s.<ref name="chien" /> Stuxnet installs malware into memory block DB890 of the PLC that monitors the [[Profibus]] messaging bus of the system.<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> When certain criteria are met, it periodically modifies the frequency to 1,410 Hz and then to 2 Hz and then to 1,064 Hz, and thus affects the operation of the connected motors by changing their rotational speed.<ref name="chien" /> It also installs a rootkit – the first such documented case on this platform – that hides the malware on the system and masks the changes in rotational speed from monitoring systems.

title: Stuxnet
added: Siemens has released a detection and removal tool for Stuxnet. Siemens recommends contacting customer support if an infection is detected and advises installing Microsoft updates for security vulnerabilities and prohibiting the use of third-party [[USB flash drive]]s.<ref name="Siemens">{{cite web|url=https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/document/43876783/simatic-wincc-simatic-pcs-7%3A-information-about-malware-viruses-trojan-horses?dti=0&lc=en-WW|access-date=24 September 2010|publisher=[[Siemens]]|title=SIMATIC WinCC / SIMATIC PCS 7: Information concerning Malware / Virus / Trojan}}</ref> Siemens also advises immediately upgrading password access codes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20011095-83.html|title=Siemens warns Stuxnet targets of password risk|date=20 July 2010|access-date=17 September 2010|website=[[CNET]]|author=Tom Espiner}}</ref>

The worm's ability to reprogram external PLCs may complicate the removal procedure. Symantec's Liam O'Murchu warns that fixing Windows systems may not fully solve the infection; a thorough audit of PLCs may be necessary. Despite speculation that incorrect removal of the worm could cause damage,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/205420/siemens_stuxnet_worm_hit_industrial_systems.html|title=Siemens: Stuxnet Worm Hit Industrial Systems|publisher=IDG News}}</ref> Siemens reports that in the first four months since discovery, the malware was successfully removed from the systems of 22 customers without any adverse effects.<ref name="Siemens" /><ref name="crve">{{cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/security/news/item/Stuxnet-also-found-at-industrial-plants-in-Germany-1081469.html|title=Stuxnet also found at industrial plants in Germany |author=crve|publisher=[[The H]]|date=17 September 2010|access-date=18 September 2010}}</ref>}}

title: Stuxnet
added: Siemens has released a detection and removal tool for Stuxnet. Siemens recommends contacting customer support if an infection is detected and advises installing Microsoft updates for security vulnerabilities and prohibiting the use of third-party [[USB flash drive]]s.<ref name="Siemens">{{cite web|url=https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/document/43876783/simatic-wincc-simatic-pcs-7%3A-information-about-malware-viruses-trojan-horses?dti=0&lc=en-WW|access-date=24 September 2010|publisher=[[Siemens]]|title=SIMATIC WinCC / SIMATIC PCS 7: Information concerning Malware / Virus / Trojan}}</ref> Siemens also advises immediately upgrading password access codes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20011095-83.html|title=Siemens warns Stuxnet targets of password risk|date=20 July 2010|access-date=17 September 2010|website=[[CNET]]|author=Tom Espiner}}</ref>

The worm's ability to reprogram external PLCs may complicate the removal procedure. Symantec's Liam O'Murchu warns that fixing Windows systems may not fully solve the infection; a thorough audit of PLCs may be necessary. Despite speculation that incorrect removal of the worm could cause damage,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/205420/siemens_stuxnet_worm_hit_industrial_systems.html|title=Siemens: Stuxnet Worm Hit Industrial Systems|publisher=IDG News}}</ref> Siemens reports that in the first four months since discovery, the malware was successfully removed from the systems of 22 customers without any adverse effects.<ref name="Siemens" /><ref name="crve">{{cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/security/news/item/Stuxnet-also-found-at-industrial-plants-in-Germany-1081469.html|title=Stuxnet also found at industrial plants in Germany |author=crve|publisher=[[The H]]|date=17 September 2010|access-date=18 September 2010}}</ref>}}

title: Stuxnet
added: |quote  = "[O]ne of the great technical blockbusters in malware history".

Unlike most malware, Stuxnet does little harm to computers and networks that do not meet specific configuration requirements; "The attackers took great care to make sure that only their designated targets were hit... It was a marksman's job."{{r|broad20110115}} While the worm is promiscuous, it makes itself inert if Siemens software is not found on infected computers, and contains safeguards to prevent each infected computer from spreading the worm to more than three others, and to erase itself on 24 June 2012.{{r|gross201104}}

For its targets, Stuxnet contains, among other things, code for a [[man-in-the-middle attack]] that fakes industrial process control sensor signals so an infected system does not shut down due to detected abnormal behavior.{{r|gross201104}}{{r|broad20110115}}<ref name=SonsOfStuxnet>{{cite magazine|author1=Steven Cherry |author2=with Larry Constantine |title=Sons of Stuxnet|url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/podcast/telecom/security/sons-of-stuxnet|magazine=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=14 December 2011}}</ref> Such complexity is very unusual for [[malware]]. The worm consists of a layered attack against three different systems:
# Siemens PCS 7, WinCC and STEP7 industrial software applications that run on Windows and
# One or more Siemens S7 PLCs.

Stuxnet attacked Windows systems using an unprecedented four [[Zero-day (computing)|zero-day]] attacks (plus the [[CPLINK]] [[vulnerability (computing)|vulnerability]] and a vulnerability used by the [[Conficker]] worm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/dd452420.aspx|title=Conficker Worm: Help Protect Windows from Conficker|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|date=10 April 2009|access-date=6 December 2010}}</ref>). It is initially spread using infected removable drives such as [[USB flash drive]]s,<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /><ref name="eset_microscope" /> which contain Windows shortcut files to initiate executable code.<ref>{{cite web|last=Buda|first=Alex|title=Creating Malware using the Stuxnet LNK Exploit |url=http://www.rubydevices.com.au/blog/stuxnetLnkExploit|publisher=Ruby Devices|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> The worm then uses other exploits and techniques such as [[peer-to-peer]] [[remote procedure call]] (RPC) to infect and update other computers inside private networks that are not directly connected to the Internet.<ref name=wired /><ref>{{cite web|author=Liam O Murchu|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-p2p-component|title=Stuxnet P2P component|publisher=[[NortonLifeLock|Symantec]]|date=17 September 2010|access-date=24 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="symantec_dossier" /> The number of zero-day exploits used is unusual, as they are highly valued and [[Hacker (computer security)|malware creators]] do not typically make use of (and thus simultaneously make visible) four different zero-day exploits in the same worm.<ref name=BBC /> Amongst these exploits were remote code execution on a computer with Printer Sharing enabled,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-061 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-061.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> and the LNK/PIF vulnerability,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-046 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-046.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=2 August 2010}}</ref> in which file execution is accomplished when an icon is viewed in Windows Explorer, negating the need for user interaction.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alexander|last=Gostev|title=Myrtus and Guava, Episode MS10-061|url=https://securelist.com/blog/incidents/29747/myrtus-and-guava-episode-ms10-061/|publisher=[[Kaspersky Lab]]|access-date=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> Stuxnet is unusually large at half a megabyte in size,<ref name=wired>{{cite magazine|author=Kim Zetter |title=Blockbuster Worm Aimed for Infrastructure, But No Proof Iran Nukes Were Target|url=https://www.wired.com/2010/09/stuxnet-2/|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=23 September 2010 |access-date=4 November 2016}}</ref> and written in several different programming languages (including [[C (programming language)|C]] and [[C++]]) which is also irregular for malware.<ref name=compworld /><ref name="Keizer1" /><ref name=SonsOfStuxnet /> The Windows component of the malware is [[promiscuous]] in that it spreads relatively quickly and indiscriminately.<ref name="eset_microscope" />

The malware has both [[Protection ring|user mode and kernel mode]] [[rootkit]] ability under Windows,<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> and its [[device driver]]s have been [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the private keys of two [[public key certificate]]s that were stolen from separate well-known companies, [[JMicron]] and [[Realtek]], both located at [[Hsinchu Science Park]] in Taiwan.<ref name="eset_microscope" /><ref name=wired /> The [[Code signing|driver signing]] helped it install [[Protection ring|kernel mode]] rootkit drivers successfully without users being notified, and thus it remained undetected for a relatively long period of time.<ref name=kaspersky>{{cite web |url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2010/Kaspersky_Lab_provides_its_insights_on_Stuxnet_worm |title=Kaspersky Lab provides its insights on Stuxnet worm |publisher=Kaspersky Lab |date=24 September 2010 |access-date=27 September 2010}}</ref> Both compromised certificates have been [[Revocation list|revoked]] by [[Verisign]].

Two websites in Denmark and Malaysia were configured as [[command and control]] servers for the malware, allowing it to be updated, and for [[industrial espionage]] to be conducted by uploading information. Both of these [[domain name]]s have subsequently been redirected by their [[DNS]] service provider to [[Dynadot]] as part of a global effort to disable the malware.<ref name="symantec_dossier" />{{r|gross201104}}
According to researcher Ralph Langner,<ref>{{cite journal
}}</ref> once installed on a Windows system Stuxnet infects project files belonging to Siemens' [[WinCC]]/[[PCS 7]] SCADA control software<ref>{{cite web

}} (Step 7), and subverts a key communication library of WinCC called s7otbxdx.dll. Doing so intercepts communications between the WinCC software running under Windows and the target Siemens PLC devices that the software is able to configure and program when the two are connected via a data cable. In this way, the malware is able to install itself on PLC devices unnoticed, and subsequently to mask its presence from WinCC if the control software attempts to read an infected block of memory from the PLC system.

The malware furthermore used a [[Zero-day (computing)|zero-day exploit]] in the WinCC/SCADA database software in the form of a hard-coded database password.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-2772|title=Vulnerability Summary for CVE-2010-2772|date=22 July 2010|access-date=7 December 2010|publisher=[[National Vulnerability Database]]}}</ref>
The entirety of the Stuxnet code has not yet been disclosed, but its payload targets only those SCADA configurations that meet criteria that it is programmed to identify.{{r|gross201104}}

Stuxnet requires specific slave [[variable-frequency drive]]s (frequency converter drives) to be attached to the targeted Siemens S7-300 system and its associated modules. It only attacks those PLC systems with variable-frequency drives from two specific vendors: [[Vacon]] based in Finland and Fararo Paya based in Iran.<ref name="chien">{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-breakthrough|title=Stuxnet: A Breakthrough|author=Eric Chien|publisher=Symantec|date=12 November 2010|access-date=14 November 2010}}</ref> Furthermore, it monitors the frequency of the attached motors, and only attacks systems that spin between 807 [[Hertz|Hz]] and 1,210 Hz. This is a much higher frequency than motors operate in most industrial applications, with the notable exception of  [[gas centrifuge]]s.<ref name="chien" /> Stuxnet installs malware into memory block DB890 of the PLC that monitors the [[Profibus]] messaging bus of the system.<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> When certain criteria are met, it periodically modifies the frequency to 1,410 Hz and then to 2 Hz and then to 1,064 Hz, and thus affects the operation of the connected motors by changing their rotational speed.<ref name="chien" /> It also installs a rootkit – the first such documented case on this platform – that hides the malware on the system and masks the changes in rotational speed from monitoring systems.

added: === November 8: George W. Bush congratulates Biden and Harris ===

On November 8, former President [[George W. Bush]] (2001–2009) congratulated President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris by phone, saying: 'The American people can have confidence that this election was fundamentally fair, its integrity will be upheld, and its outcome is clear'. He further stated: 'The President-elect reiterated that while he ran as a Democrat, he will govern for all Americans. I offered him the same thing I offered Presidents Trump and Obama: my prayers for his success, and my pledge to help in any way I can.'<ref name="Bradner">{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/11/08/politics/george-w-bush-congratulates-biden/index.html |title=Bush congratulates Biden, says election was 'fundamentally fair' and 'its outcome is clear' |author=Eric Bradner |work=CNN |date=November 8, 2020 |accessdate=November 8, 2020}}</ref>

He further stated: 'The President-elect reiterated that while he ran as a Democrat, he will govern for all Americans. I offered him the same thing I offered Presidents Trump and Obama: my prayers for his success, and my pledge to help in any way I can.' While congratulating Trump 'on a hard-fought campaign' and saying he 'has the right to request recounts and pursue legal challenges', Bush stated the outcome of the election was clearly in Biden's favor.<ref name="Bradner">{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/11/08/politics/george-w-bush-congratulates-biden/index.html |title=Bush congratulates Biden, says election was 'fundamentally fair' and 'its outcome is clear' |author=Eric Bradner |work=CNN |date=November 8, 2020 |accessdate=November 8, 2020}}</ref><refname="Baker">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/08/us/politics/george-w-bush-congratulates-biden-on-his-victory.html |title=George W. title: Republican reactions to Donald Trump's claims of 2020 election fraud
added: === November 9: Trump campaign announces legal challenges ===

The Trump campaign team announced it would formally present several legal challenges against the election process and results on Monday, November 9, refusing to concede the Biden/Harris victory. However, speaking on the condition of anonimity to the Associated Press, senior officials, campaign aides and allies said that '[t]he strategy to wage a legal fight against the votes tallied for Biden in Pennsylvania and other places is more to provide Trump with an off-ramp for a loss he can't quite grasp and less about changing the election's outcome'. Some of them even had 'deep reservations about the president's attempts to undermine faith in the vote'.<ref name="LongMiller">{{Cite news |url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-virus-outbreak-pennsylvania-e1c3c5147d11a033fb43ebe66a29f7e8 |title=Fraud claims aimed in part at keeping Trump base loyal |author=Colleen Long & Zeke Miller |work=Associated Press |date=November 9, 2020 |accessdate=November 9, 2020}}</ref>

title: Republican reactions to Donald Trump's claims of 2020 election fraud
deleted: On November 10, Secretary of State [[Mike Pompeo]] sparked outrage among diplomats when he told journalists during a press conference that there would be a 'smooth transition to a second Trump administration', because he was confident that the vote counting would still result in a Trump victory.<ref name="Gaouette"/> [[John Bolton]], National Security Advisor in the Trump administration from 2018 to 2019, who had already denounced Trump's fraud claims days earlier,<ref name="Crowley"/> was highly critical of Pompeo's remarks, saying he had 'eviscerated his credibility' and was 'delusional'.<ref name="Blitzer">{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/11/11/mike-pompeo-trump-transition-john-bolton-response-blitzer-tsr-vpx.cnn |title=Mike Pompeo 'has eviscerated his credibility': Bolton |author=Wolf Blitzer |work=CNN |date=November 10, 2020 |accessdate=November 10, 2020}}</ref> Meanwhile, Democratic Senator [[Chris Coons]] from Delaware told CNN that several Republican senators had privately acknowledged President-elect Joe Biden's victory to him in phone calls, asking him 'to convey their well-wishes to the President-elect', but they weren't yet willing to do so publicly themselves. At that point, four Republican senators had publicly recognized Biden, and Coons expected others to follow that week.<ref name="Coons">{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/11/10/chris-coons-gop-senators-biden-win-vpx.cnn |title=Senator: Some Republicans are privately acknowledging Biden's win |author= |work=CNN |date=November 10, 2020 |accessdate=November 10, 2020}}</ref>
