deleted: Since before his presidency Donald Trump has disavowed white supremacists and all hate groups.<ref>{{Cite web|title=38 Times President Trump Has Condemned Racism and White Supremacy - YouTube|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bd0cMmBvqWc&ab_channel=DonaldJTrump|access-date=2020-11-05|website=www.youtube.com}}</ref>

title: Social policy of the first Donald Trump administration
deleted: In 2012, prior to running for the presidency, Trump called for the exclusion of trans women from [[beauty pageant]]s. He did not want [[Jenna Talackova]] to compete in the [[Miss USA]] pageants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2012/04/donald-trump-has-words-for-transgender-miss-universe-contestant|title=Donald Trump Has Words for Transgender Miss Universe Contestant|last=Kindelan|first=Katie|date=4 April 2012|website=ABC News|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190519222021/https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2012/04/donald-trump-has-words-for-transgender-miss-universe-contestant/|archive-date=19 May 2019|access-date=13 March 2020}}</ref>

At a rally in October 2016, Trump called the open military service of transgender Americans a result of a "political correct military". He said he said he would seek new recommendations from military leaders on the topic of transgender personnel and would "very strongly" defer to those recommendations.<ref>Jenna Johnson, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/10/03/heres-how-trump-responded-to-a-question-about-women-and-transgender-individuals-in-the-military/ Here's how Trump responded to a question about women and transgender individuals in the military] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131143626/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/10/03/heres-how-trump-responded-to-a-question-about-women-and-transgender-individuals-in-the-military/ |date=2017-01-31 }}, ''Washington Post'' (October 3, 2016).</ref>

In April 2016, Trump criticized North Carolina's [[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act|North Carolina House Bill 2]], which eliminated all private employment and public accommodation anti-discrimination laws that were stricter than statewide law and required that, in government buildings, individuals may [[Bathroom bill|use only restrooms and changing facilities that correspond to the sex on their birth certificates]]. The bill was controversial because it prevented transgender people who do not or cannot alter their birth certificates from using the restroom consistent with their [[gender identity]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/how-north-carolina-signed-a-bill-dubbed-the-most-anti-lgbt-law-in-the-u-s/|title=How North Carolina signed a bill dubbed the most anti-LGBT law in the U.S.|date=March 24, 2016|website=pbs.org|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|accessdate=May 9, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506173908/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/how-north-carolina-signed-a-bill-dubbed-the-most-anti-lgbt-law-in-the-u-s/|archive-date=May 6, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kopan|first1=Tal|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/23/politics/north-carolina-gender-bathrooms-bill/|title=North Carolina governor signs controversial transgender bill|date=March 24, 2016|accessdate=May 9, 2016|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|last2=Scott|first2=Eugene|website=cnn.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508133409/http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/23/politics/north-carolina-gender-bathrooms-bill/|archive-date=May 8, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article68401147.html|title=Understanding HB2: North Carolina's newest law solidifies state's role in defining discrimination|last1=Gordon|first1=Michael|last2=Price|first2=Mark S.|date=March 26, 2016|website=charlotteobserver.com|publisher=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|accessdate=May 9, 2016|last3=Peralta|first3=Katie|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508110530/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article68401147.html|archive-date=May 8, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/north-carolinas-controversial-anti-lgbt-bill-explained/story?id=37898153|title=North Carolina's Controversial 'Anti-LGBT' Bill Explained|last=Tan|first=Avianne|date=March 24, 2016|website=abcnews.go.com|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|accessdate=May 9, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510152549/https://abcnews.go.com/US/north-carolinas-controversial-anti-lgbt-bill-explained/story?id=37898153|archive-date=May 10, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Trump said: "North Carolina did something that was very strong and they're paying a big price.{{nbsp}}... You leave it the way it is. There have been very few complaints the way it is. People go, they use the bathroom they feel is appropriate, there has been so little trouble, and the problem with what happened in North Carolina is the strife, and the economic punishment that they're taking."<ref>Sam Levine, [https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-north-carolina-bathroom-bill_us_5718ca1ee4b0c9244a7aec8c Donald Trump Thinks North Carolina Got It Wrong On Anti-LGBT Bathroom Bill] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109163900/https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-north-carolina-bathroom-bill_us_5718ca1ee4b0c9244a7aec8c |date=2018-11-09 }}, ''Huffington Post'' (April 21, 2016).</ref><ref>David A. Graham, [https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/04/trump-transgender-bathroom-north-carolina/479316/ Donald Trump's Case for Tolerance] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204194553/https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/04/trump-transgender-bathroom-north-carolina/479316/ |date=2017-02-04 }}, ''The Atlantic'' (April 21, 2016).</ref> He also said: "I fully understand if they [North Carolina] want to go through, but they are losing business and they are having a lot of people come out against."<ref name="GrahamNCLaw">David A. Graham, [https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/04/trump-north-carolina-transgender-law/479547/ Did Trump Change His Mind on North Carolina's Transgender Law?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224001418/https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/04/trump-north-carolina-transgender-law/479547/ |date=2017-02-24 }}, ''The Atlantic'' (April 22, 2016).</ref> Later that month, however, Trump expressed the opposite position that states have the right to enact such legislation and that the federal government should not become involved.<ref name=":38">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-hb2-lgbt_us_577d4443e4b09b4c43c1e90d|title=Donald Trump Now Apparently Supports North Carolina's Anti-LGBT Law|last=Mollie Reilly Deputy Politics Editor|first=The Huffington Post|date=July 6, 2016|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=July 7, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706221737/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-hb2-lgbt_us_577d4443e4b09b4c43c1e90d|archive-date=July 6, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> He did not express an opinion on whether the law was right or wrong.<ref name="GrahamNCLaw"/> In July 2016, Trump again emphasized a states' rights approach regarding HB2,<ref name=":37">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/election/article87877837.html|title=Backstage with Donald Trump before his Raleigh speech|newspaper=The News & Observer|accessdate=July 7, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706174803/http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/election/article87877837.html|archive-date=July 6, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/23/us/politics/donald-trump-gay-rights.html?_r=0|title=Donald Trump's More Accepting Views on Gay Issues Set Him Apart in G.O.P.|accessdate=October 24, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Maggie|last=Haberman|date=April 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118235504/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/23/us/politics/donald-trump-gay-rights.html?_r=0|archive-date=November 18, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> saying, "The state, they know what's going on, they see what's happening and generally speaking I'm with the state on things like this. I've spoken with your governor, I've spoken with a lot of people and I'm going with the state."<ref name=":38"/><ref name=":37"/>

title: Ron Paul
added: Ron Paul's presidential campaign managers [[Jesse Benton]], John Tate and Demetri Kesari were all found guilty of paying former Iowa State Senator [[Kent Sorenson]] $73,000 to switch his support from Rep. [[Michele Bachmann]] to Paul.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.apnews.com/b7d508267328424d8822b83cce7375ac |date=May 11, 2018 |title=Court upholds convictions of 2012 Ron Paul campaign staffers |first=David |last=Pitt |work=Associated Press }}</ref> In court papers filed in August 2014, Sorenson said that he had been paid by both presidential campaigns for his endorsement and pled guilty to criminal charges stemming from the incident.<ref>{{cite news | first=Matea | last=Gold |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/08/27/former-iowa-state-senator-pleads-guilty-in-ron-paul-endorsement-for-pay-scheme/| title=Former Iowa state senator pleads guilty in Ron Paul endorsement-for-pay scheme | newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 27, 2014 | date=August 27, 2014}}</ref>

title: Ron Paul
deleted: In December 2011, with Paul's increased support, the controversy over racist and homophobic statements in several Ron Paul newsletters in the 1980s and early 1990s once again gained media attention.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/20/us/politics/bias-in-ron-pauls-newsletters-draws-new-attention.html |title=New Focus on Incendiary Words in Paul's Newsletters |work=[[The New York Times]] }}</ref> During this time Paul supporters asserted that he was continually ignored by the media despite his significant support, citing examples of where television news shows would fail to mention Paul in discussions of the Republican presidential hopefuls even when he was polling second.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ron |last=Smith |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-08-18/news/bs-ed-smith-20110818_1_herman-cain-invisible-candidate-gop-presidential-debate |title=Ron Paul, aka the invisible candidate |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418181938/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-08-18/news/bs-ed-smith-20110818_1_herman-cain-invisible-candidate-gop-presidential-debate |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |work=[[Baltimore Sun]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Bruce |last=Ramsey |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/edcetera/2015926924_post.html |title=Ron Paul Ignored |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019071706/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/edcetera/2015926924_post.html |archivedate=October 19, 2011 |work=Seattle Times }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Frank |last=James |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2011/08/16/139669952/ron-paul-wears-invisibility-cloak-in-medias-eyes?t=1561471109486 |title=Ron Paul Wears Invisibility Cloak In News Media's Eyes |work=[[NPR]] }}</ref>

title: Ilhan Omar
added: According to filings with the [[Federal Election Commission]], Omar's political campaign paid her husband's consulting firm nearly $2.8 million during the course of the 2019-2020 election cycle.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Dorman|first=Sam|date=2020-11-10|title=Ilhan Omar's campaign paid her husband's firm nearly $2.8M|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/ilhan-omar-husband-campaign-firm|access-date=2020-11-13|website=Fox News|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Ilhan Omar
deleted: In 2017, at a moment when the government of Turkey had jailed more than 50,000 academics, teachers, journalists, court officials, judges, police, and military personnel following the failed [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|coup]] of 2016, then-State Representative Omar participated in a closed-door meeting with Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] in New York City.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Erdogan Ally Met With Omar, Contributed to Her Campaign|url=https://news.yahoo.com/erdogan-ally-met-omar-contributed-124904962.html|access-date=2020-11-01|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Bendix|first=Aria|date=2017-07-14|title=Turkey Dismisses Thousands of Police, Civil Servants, and Academics|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2017/07/turkey-dismisses-thousands-of-police-civil-servants-and-academics/533754/|access-date=2020-11-01|website=The Atlantic|language=en-US}}</ref>

In her official explanation of her decision to vote "present" on H.Res. 296 to [[Armenian Genocide recognition|recognize]] the [[Armenian Genocide|Armenian genocide]], Omar appeared to use specific language and arguments, including the phrase "leave it do the academic consensus" promoted by the Turkish government and its lobbyists.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Swanson|first=Ian|date=2019-11-01|title=Omar comes under scrutiny for 'present' vote on Armenian genocide|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/468446-omar-comes-under-scrutiny-for-present-vote-on-armenian-genocide|access-date=2020-11-01|website=TheHill|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Ilhan Omar faces blowback after voting 'present' on Armenian genocide resolution|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ilhan-omar-faces-blowback-after-voting-present-armenian-genocide-resolution-n1073991|access-date=2020-11-01|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Erdogan reminded of Armenian Genocide during G20 presser|url=https://news.am/eng/news/484212.html|access-date=2020-11-01|website=news.am|language=en}}</ref> Another argument advanced by Omar, that "true acknowledgment of historical crimes against humanity must include … earlier mass slaughters like the transatlantic slave trade and Native American genocide," was described by Slate magazine as "classic what-aboutism."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Keating|first=Joshua|date=2019-10-30|title=Of Course Congress’ Vote to Recognize the Armenian Genocide Was Political|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/10/armenian-genocide-resolution-ilhan-omar-congress.html|access-date=2020-11-01|website=Slate Magazine|language=en}}</ref>

In an op-ed published in October 2019, Omar argued against imposing sanctions on Turkey on the grounds that sanctions tend to hurt ordinary citizens in the country sanctioned, but suggested that sanctions targeting individuals or the purchase of arms were more appropriate;<ref>{{Cite news|last=Omar|first=Ilhan|title=Opinion {{!}} Ilhan Omar: Sanctions are part of a failed foreign policy playbook. Stop relying on them.|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/ilhan-omar-sanctions-are-part-of-a-failed-foreign-policy-playbook-stop-relying-on-them/2019/10/23/b7cbb1ca-f510-11e9-a285-882a8e386a96_story.html|access-date=2020-11-01|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Omar then voted against a sanctions bill that was designed to target banks or entities involved in the arm trade on behalf of Turkey.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Edmondson|first=Catie|date=2019-10-29|title=In Another Bipartisan Rebuke of Trump, House Votes for Sanctions Against Turkey (Published 2019)|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/29/us/politics/house-turkey-sanctions.html|access-date=2020-11-01|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Engel|first=Eliot L.|date=2019-10-30|title=H.R.4695 - 116th Congress (2019-2020): PACT Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/4695|access-date=2020-11-01|website=www.congress.gov}}</ref>

In 2019, it was revealed that Omar had received a large campaign donation from a Turkish [[Advocacy group|lobbying group]] led by, Halil Mutlu, a cousin of President Erdogan.<ref name=":0" /> Mutlu was present at the 2017 clash between [[Clashes at the Turkish Ambassador's Residence in Washington, D.C.|Erdogan's bodyguards]] and peaceful protestors in Washington D.C.<ref name=":0" />

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: The [[Connecticut legislature]] had failed to elect a senator for the term beginning in 1851.  Democrat [[Isaac Toucey]] was elected in May 1852 to finish the term.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: Democratic senator [[William K. Sebastian]] had been appointed May 12, 1848 to continue the term, to which he was elected later that year to finish.
Sebastian was re-elected to a full term in 1853.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: One-term Whig [[Joseph R. Underwood]] retired and Know Nothing [[John Burton Thompson]] was elected.

Long-term Whig and former-[[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Henry Clay]] died June 24, 1852 and Democrat [[David Meriwether (Kentucky)|David Meriwether]] was appointed July 6, 1852 pending a special election, in which he was not a candidate.
Whig [[Archibald Dixon]] was elected September 1, 1852 to finish the term that would end in 1855.
In 1853 the [[Kentucky legislature]] elected Whig former senator [[John J. Crittenden]] to succeed Dixon, far in advance of the 1855 term.

title: Senate Intelligence Committee report on Russian interference in the 2016 United States presidential election
Senate Intelligence Committee report on Russian interference in the 2016 United States presidential election
added: The committee described that Trump's presidential campaign "sought to maximize the impact of those leaks to aid Trump’s electoral prospects". The Trump campaign "created messaging strategies to promote and share" the material, and "encouraged further leaks". The Trump campaign tasked Trump associate [[Roger Stone]] to gather information about WikiLeaks' release of the material; Stone reported to Trump or senior campaign members.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Spencer |first1=Saranac |title=Partisan Claims of ‘Russia Hoax’ Revived Ahead of 2020 Election |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/10/partisan-claims-of-russia-hoax-revived-ahead-of-2020-election/ |publisher=[[FactCheck.org]] |accessdate=November 11, 2020}}</ref>

title: Lauren Underwood
added: In 2019, Underwood was listed in [[Time (magazine)|Time]] 100, with her entry being written by U.S. Senator [[Cory Booker]].<ref>{{cite web |title=TIME 100 Next 2019: Lauren Underwood |url=https://time.com/collection/time-100-next-2019/5718829/lauren-underwood/ |website=Time |accessdate=15 November 2020 |language=en-us |date=2019}}</ref>

title: Pat Cipollone
added: On January 31, 2020, it was reported that Cipollone was present at a May 2019 White House meeting where President Trump directed his national security adviser John Bolton to "extract damaging information on Democrats from Ukrainian officials."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/us/politics/trump-bolton-ukraine.html|title=Trump Told Bolton to Help His Ukraine Pressure Campaign, Book Says|last=Haberman|first=Maggie|date=2020-01-31|work=The New York Times|access-date=2020-01-31|last2=Schmidt|first2=Michael S.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Paul Gosar
added: In 2020, Gosar joined fellow congressmember [[Andy Biggs]] in a video produced by the [[Arizona Republican Party]] claiming that there was [[2020_United_States_presidential_election#Trump's_potential_rejection_of_election_results|widespread voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election]] in which Joe Biden was declared the winner. Gosar claimed voting machines were faulty in Arizona and that Wisconsin intentionally paused counting votes to "dump" 100,000 votes into the count for Joe Biden. Gosar also claims that deceased people voted in Pennsylvania. All of Gosar's allegations have been debunked. Gosar and Biggs also demanded an audit of Maricopa County's vote count.<ref name="Hansen">{{cite news |last1=Hansen |first1=Ronald J. |title=FACT CHECK: Reps. Andy Biggs, Paul Gosar still touting baseless election-fraud claims |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/fact-check/2020/11/17/andy-biggs-paul-gosar-still-touting-baseless-election-fraud-claims/6334872002/ |accessdate=20 November 2020 |work=The Arizona Republic |date=17 November 2020}}</ref> Gosar also participated in [[Stop the Steal]] protests, comparing their efforts to the [[Battle of the Alamo]].<ref name="OBrien">{{cite news |last1=O'Brien |first1=Luke |title=Republican Congressman Helped Organize Far-Right Protest Against Election Result |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/paul-gosar-far-right-protest-arizona_n_5fada218c5b6370e7e311861 |accessdate=20 November 2020 |work=HuffPost |date=13 November 2020 |language=en}}</ref>

title: Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
added: According to the New York Times, Trump’s team did always intend to hold the press conference at Four Seasons Total Landscapting, but the president got a bit confused. The mistake was not in the booking, but in the misunderstanding of the telephone correspondence to Trump. <ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=US Election 2020: Trump laywer Rudy Giuliani’s Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference mistake goes viral|url=https://www.news.com.au/world/north-america/us-politics/us-election-trump-laywer-rudy-giulianis-four-seasons-total-landscaping-press-conference-mistake-goes-viral/news-story/0adff3225ed3ae9e8478874565749f85|url-status=live|access-date=9 November 2020|website=|publisher=News.com.au}}</ref>

title: Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
added: According to''[[TheNew York Times]]'',Trump'steam did always intend to hold the press conference at Four Seasons TotalLandscaping, but the president got confused. The mistake was not in the booking, but in the misunderstanding of the telephone correspondence to Trump.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=US Election 2020: Trump laywer Rudy Giuliani’s Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference mistake goes viral|url=https://www.news.com.au/world/north-america/us-politics/us-election-trump-laywer-rudy-giulianis-four-seasons-total-landscaping-press-conference-mistake-goes-viral/news-story/0adff3225ed3ae9e8478874565749f85|url-status=live|access-date=9 November 2020|website=|publisher=News.com.au}}</ref>

title: Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
added: Journalists who arrived took note of the surrounding [[industrial park]]. "It was in that part of town that every town has, where businesses which have no right being grouped together nonetheless gather due to one reason or another—usually the cheap rent" observed the British newspaper ''[[The Independent]]''. Across the street was a [[sex shop]] and [[crematorium]].<ref name="Independent story" />

title: Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
added: The event drew ridicule and parody on [[social media]], where it was assumed the Trump campaign had simply made a mistake with the booking. [[Yelp]] users posted joke reviews; ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''{{'}}s [[Kate McKinnon]] mentioned Four Seasons in an appearance as Giuliani on the show's "[[Weekend Update]]" news segment.<ref name="Bucks County Courier Times story">{{cite news|last=Ciavaglia|first=Jo|title=What we know about Four Seasons Total Landscaping, the most famous business in Philly today|url=https://www.buckscountycouriertimes.com/story/news/2020/11/08/four-seasons-landscaping-philadelphia-trump-campaign/6212732002/|newspaper=[[Bucks County Courier Times]]|location=[[Levittown, Pennsylvania]]|date=November 8, 2020|accessdate=November 9, 2020}}</ref> Four Seasons

For the rest of the weekend, visitors came to the building to take pictures of themselves with the company gates and logo in the background. Some carried pro-Biden and anti-Trump signs. On Sunday Four Seasons announced it would begin selling T-shirts and other merchandise through its website the next day.<ref name="Not that Four Seasons" />

title: Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference
added: During the press conference, Corey Lewandowski cited one case of what he said was a documented deceased Pennsylvania voter Denise Ondick, of Homestead, near Pittsburgh. Records appeared to support his claim that an online obituary and her family claimed that Ondick, a registered Democrat, died at age 74 on October 22. But voting records show a mail-in ballot was sent to her home on Oct. 24, two days after death, and that it was sent back and received by election officials on November 2. The individual mail ballot tracking system of the state Secretary of State says that this vote was "recorded."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inquirer.com/news/trump-biden-vote-fraud-philadelphia-pittsburgh-rudy-giuliani-lawsuits-20201108.html|title=Trump legal team vows to fight on, starting with fresh lawsuit Monday in Pennsylvania|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=November 8, 2020 |accessdate=November 9, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rev.com/blog/transcripts/rudy-giuliani-trump-campaign-philadelphia-press-conference-november-7|title=Rudy Giuliani Trump Campaign Philadelphia Press Conference November 7 (Transcript)|work=REV|date=November 7, 2020 |accessdate=November 9, 2020}}</ref>

deleted: Ondish's family confirmed that she had received an absentee ballot application; her daughter said she had helped her mother, who planned to vote for Trump, fill it out two days prior to her death and the state records show the application was received the day after Ondish died. But she had not mailed the ballot in after her mother died, and she said her father could not recall doing so. She did not believe her parents would willfully violate the law. Election officials in Allegheny County said they would investigate.<ref name="Inky Sunday story" />

title: Pete Buttigieg
added: In February 2012, soon after taking office, Buttigieg and the board of the South Bend Housing Authority requested that the [[Department of Housing and Urban Development]] conduct a "full audit and investigation" of allegations of improperly awarded contracts and misallocated funds in the South Bend Housing Authority.<ref name="housingauthoritytimeline"/> In 20-13, federal officials outlined "dire" mismanagement and financial problems, and faulted the board with failure to provide proper oversight to the agency and catch its problems.<ref name="housingauthoritytimeline"/> In October 2014, after the board failed to submit a plan to fix the agencies problems, the federal officials urged Buttigieg to take action, "including the possibility of replacing all or some existing board members".<ref name="housingauthoritytimeline"/> In January 2015, after all six of the board's members either resigned or saw their terms expire, Buttigieg appointed six new members.<ref name="housingauthoritytimeline"/>

title: Pete Buttigieg
added: In 2017, Buttgieig signed the "We're Still In" letter, voicing South Bend's commitment to the goals of the [[Paris Climate Agreement]].<ref name="carbonneutral"/> In 2018, he joined the Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate and Energy.<ref name="carbonneutral"/> Also in 2018, Buttigieg signed the “Repower Indiana" letter, urging utility companies to supply 100% clean energy.<ref name="carbonneutral"/> In 2019, he signed onto the "Mayors for Solar Energy" letter resolving to make solar energy a key element of the city.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Searson |first1=Emma |title=Press Release: Mayors Hamilton, Buttigieg Among Five Indiana Mayors for Solar Energy {{!}} City of Bloomington, Indiana |url=https://bloomington.in.gov/news/2019/07/25/4155 |website=bloomington.in.gov |publisher=Bloomington, Indiana |accessdate=20 November 2020 |date=25 July 2019}}</ref>

In late November of 2019, the city's Common Council voted 7–0 to approve Buttigeig's "Carbon Neutral 2050" plan, setting the goal of meeting the Paris accord's 26% emission reduction by 2025, and aiming for a further reductions of 45% by 2035.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Parrott |first1=Jeff |title=South Bend council approves Pete Buttigieg climate plan, while activists urge going further |url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/local/south-bend-council-approves-pete-buttigieg-climate-plan-while-activists-urge-going-further/article_441cf3b7-fe20-5a5c-adf1-e0c7a90db588.html |website=South Bend Tribune |accessdate=20 November 2020 |language=en |date=26 November 2019}}</ref>

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
deleted: Observers had been suggesting for months about the possibility of a premature Trump victory claim and then a contested election based on the likelihood that the initial votes counted by Election Night would skew heavily Republican. This was because [[mail-in voting|mail-in ballots]] were expected to lean heavily Democratic, leading to a [[blue shift (politics)|blue shift]] that becomes more favorable to Biden as more votes are counted.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Chang|first=Alvin|date=2020-11-01|title='Blue shift': why votes counted after election day skew to the Democrats|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/01/why-itll-be-normal-if-results-shift-in-the-days-after-the-election|access-date=2020-11-05|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

* {{flag|Australia}}: [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Scott Morrison]] said he planned on remaining neutral, not commenting on the protests;<ref name= ScoMoNotSpeculateClaimsOfFraud>{{Cite web|last=Stayner|first=Tom|title=Scott Morrison says 'it's not for him' to speculate on Donald Trump's claims of electoral fraud|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/scott-morrison-says-it-s-not-for-him-to-speculate-on-donald-trump-s-claims-of-electoral-fraud|access-date=2020-11-05|website=SBS News|language=en-AU}}</ref> Leader of the Opposition [[Anthony Albanese]] urged all votes to be counted: "People shouting in a chant stop the count - that's really shouting stop democracy. [...] America will come through this."<ref name="ScoMoNotSpeculateClaimsOfFraud" /> [[Marise Payne]], similar to Scott Morrison, refused to provide a "running commentary" but expressed the importance of every vote being counted.<ref name= MarisePayneInterviewed>{{Cite web|author=Department of Foreign Affairs & Trade|title=Interview with Lisa Millar, ABC News Breakfast|url=https://www.foreignminister.gov.au/minister/marise-payne/transcript/interview-lisa-millar-abc-news-breakfast|access-date=2020-11-05|website=Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|language=en-AU}}</ref>

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
deleted: In remarks from the [[White House]] on the early hours of November 4, President Trump attacked the vote counting efforts, calling it "fraud" with no basis. The president remarked, "We will win this. As far as I'm concerned, we already have won."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Videos|first= Ian Schwartz, RCP|title=Trump: "We Did Win This Election," "This Is A Major Fraud On Our Nation"|url= https://www.https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2020/11/04/trump_we_did_win_this_election_this_is_a_major_fraud_on_our_nation.html|website= Real Clear Politics}}</ref> The major networks carried Trump's speech in full, but aired fact-checks after it had concluded.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Business|first=Brian Stelter, CNN|title=What will TV and social networks do if Trump prematurely declares victory?|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/02/media/tv-networks-election-night-victory/index.html|access-date=2020-11-05|website=CNN}}</ref> Furthermore, former [[Counselor to the President|White House Chief Strategist]] [[Steve Bannon]] suggested violence against Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]] and FBI Director [[Christopher A. Wray]] could serve as “a warning to federal bureaucrats” to begin a second term for President Trump.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Reimann|first=Nicholas|title=Steve Bannon Condemned, Banned From Twitter After Suggesting Violence As ‘A Warning To Federal Bureaucrats’|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nicholasreimann/2020/11/05/steve-bannon-condemned-banned-from-twitter-after-suggesting-violence-as-a-warning-to-federal-bureaucrats/|access-date=2020-11-06|website=Forbes|language=en}}</ref>

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
deleted: In [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] hundreds of [[anarchists]] and [[anti-fascists]] protested throughout Portland, against both presidential candidates. Protesters carried signs stating "Strong communities make politicians obsolete", "We don't want Biden we want revenge", and chanted "fuck Biden". Protesters began [[rioting]] near an ICE detention center facility, and the [[Oregon Army National Guard]] was sent into Portland. 17 protesters were arrested.<ref>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-police-arrest-11-in-portland-50-in-new-york-at-protests-after-us/</ref>

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
added: *In [[Pittsburgh]], Multiple protests were organized by several groups like Pittsburgh United, United Steelworkers, Pennsylvania Interfaith Impact Network, and Bend the Arc to “count every vote.”<ref>{{Cite web|last=Haile|first=Nardos|title=Over 100 protest in Pittsburgh, calling on Pennsylvania to "Count Every Vote"|url=https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/over-100-protest-in-pittsburgh-calling-on-pennsylvania-to-count-every-vote/Content?oid=18314866|access-date=2020-11-16|website=Pittsburgh City Paper|language=en}}</ref>

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
added: The weekend after the election, Infowars host Alex Jones, along with crew members Owen Shroyer and Ali Alexander, announced they would send a caravan of vehicles from Austin, TX to Washington D.C. starting the next day to rally support for Donald Trump (https://parler.com/post/4e08833557c6497c839511f82f4dfeb9). Infowars contributor Ali Alexander suggested / started the hashtag #marchfortrump, and announced a march for Trump in Washington D.C., scheduled for Saturday, November 14.  The march was not anticipated to be massive at that time.  Infowars publicized the event for the first time on Sunday, 11/8/2020.  The next day, upon hearing about the ‘Stop the Steal Caravan’ and the ‘March For Trump,’ alt-pop musician Adam Metropolis started the hashtag #millionMAGAmarch on Parler, and began making promo images & videos for that concept.  Metropolis did this completely independently, having no relationship with Infowars.  The origin of the name ‘Million MAGA March’ was on Monday, 11/9 (https://parler.com/post/07bc7707d42a4f5397dc4ae1d2afecaf).

The concept was, according to Adam, to create a manipulative title that would encourage Trump-supporters to think the turn-out was going to be good, so they would be more likely to go.  It was also to anger media outlets to increase coverage.

Adam pushed promos on the social media platforms Parler, Minds, MeWe, and Gab. Harrison Smith, an Infowars anchor, saw the hashtag and began using the term “Million MAGA March” live on air during Infowars’ “The War Room” on Monday, 11/9. At this time there was still no time or location set for the so-called ‘Million MAGA March.’   The next day, the Proud Boys had announced “The Million MAGA March” publicly, and the event spread virally on Parler & Minds.

Adam Metropolis contacted news sources in the US and internationally, giving a news tip about a horrible Trump rally where there would be no masks or social distancing.  He did this under ghe pseudonym ‘Calvin Ennis.’  (All outgoing emails can be forwarded for historical record.)

Soon, viral content was promoting “Global Protests” (https://parler.com/post/186071c90bb944bea625ed01ed62f125 ) and called for people around the world to rise up against COVID19 lockdowns.  The event was seen as a revolt against global government, not merely a rally event for Trump.

Because this event was first announced on Sunday, 11/8, and considering the nature of its evolution into what it became, it is of historical significance.  Far-right conspiracy theorist Alex Jones gave the keynote speech at the steps of the Supreme Court, in which he expressed at least two overt calls for violence, mentioning Bill Gates by name (https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=youtu.be&v=wDXe6XhsoGU&app=desktop).  He claims Donald Trump won the election, and He calls Joe Biden “a Chinese spy” and claims Biden’s family members are “Satanic pedophiles,” to roaring applause.
Media outlets are consistently claiming a turnout of thousands, but review of the UK Guardian footage reveals more than 100,000 in Freedom Plaza an hour before the event began.
Mayor Muriel Bowser shut down 10 blocks of Washington D.C. for the March, and also partially suspended  Metrorail service the morning of the event.
Alex Jones gave a bullhorn speech in Freedom Plaza at 11:45am (https://parler.com/post/edb8475eadcd4ba1bddfe68fc5344079 )
The march started at around noon. Footage:  The procession went uphill to the Supreme Court, with new supporters flowing in until at least 2 p.m.
Police estimated total turnout to be over a million:   (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Esy3Dak7uXs&app=desktop)
Jones had at least 30 Proud Boys protecting him, and video footage from Parler reveals at least 300 Proud Boys / 3% / Oathkeepers wearing body armor at the event. (Parler: # millionMAGAmarch)
The following shows some of the turnout, both photographed pointing downhill:
The next night, pro-Trump protesters showed up at the Clintons’ house to harass them:  https://parler.com/post/186071c90bb944bea625ed01ed62f125

Whatvis striking is that a handful of activists threw together a protest of over a million people in 6 days - and it was completely decentralized.  There were still no permits relating to the March as of Wed, Nov 11 (https://www.washingtonian.com/2020/11/11/million-maga-march-organizers-still-dont-have-a-permit/).

title: 2020–21 United States election protests
deleted:
The [[Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign|Trump campaign]] has challenged the legitimacy of the election results by filing lawsuits, demanding [[Election recount|recounts]], alleging that [[Postal voting in the United States|mail voting]] is responsible for widespread electoral fraud, and claiming without evidence that election officials are conspiring to help Democrats.{{Cite news |last=Young |first=Ashley |date=September 23, 2016 |title=A Complete Guide To Early And Absentee Voting |language=en |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/23/491999689/a-complete-guide-to-early-and-absentee-voting |access-date=June 15, 2020 |archive-date=November 16, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116035304/https://www.npr.org/2016/09/23/491999689/a-complete-guide-to-early-and-absentee-voting |url-status=live }}(1) {{Cite web|last=Farley|first=Robert|date=April 10, 2020|title=Trump's Latest Voter Fraud Misinformation|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/04/trumps-latest-voter-fraud-misinformation/|website=FactCheck.org|language=en-US|access-date=June 19, 2020|archive-date=November 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116035239/https://www.factcheck.org/2020/04/trumps-latest-voter-fraud-misinformation/|url-status=live}}
(2) {{cite news|date=July 30, 2020|title=Donald Trump suggests delay to 2020 US presidential election|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-53597975|accessdate=July 31, 2020|archive-date=July 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200730223245/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-53597975|url-status=live}}
(3) {{Cite news|last=Morello|first=Carol|date=November 4, 2020|title=European election observers decry Trump’s ‘baseless allegations’ of voter fraud|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/election-observers-trump-allegations/2020/11/04/4a538500-1ee0-11eb-9ec3-3a81e23c4b5e_story.html|url-status=live|access-date=November 6, 2020|issn=0190-8286|archive-date=November 5, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201105161029/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/election-observers-trump-allegations/2020/11/04/4a538500-1ee0-11eb-9ec3-3a81e23c4b5e_story.html}}
(4) {{cite web|first=Chris|last=Cillizza|title=Here's the *real* reason Donald Trump is attacking mail-in ballots|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/26/politics/mail-in-ballot-vote-by-mail-trump/index.html|date=May 26, 2020|access-date=June 29, 2020|website=CNN|archive-date=July 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200730153554/https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/26/politics/mail-in-ballot-vote-by-mail-trump/index.html|url-status=live}}
(5) {{cite news|last1=Haberman|first1=Maggie|last2=Corasaniti|first2=Nick|last3=Qiu|first3=Linda|date=June 24, 2020|title=Trump's Attacks on Voting by Mail Stir Broad Concern|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/24/us/politics/trump-vote-by-mail.html|access-date=June 29, 2020|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=July 29, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729030608/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/24/us/politics/trump-vote-by-mail.html|url-status=live}} Trump has consistently refused to commit to a [[United States presidential transition|transfer of power]].{{cite news|last=King|first=Ledyard|date=November 7, 2020|title=Trump revives baseless claims of election fraud after Biden wins presidential race|work=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/07/joe-biden-victory-president-trump-claims-election-far-over/6202892002/|accessdate=November 7, 2020|archive-date=November 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201108054219/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/07/joe-biden-victory-president-trump-claims-election-far-over/6202892002/|url-status=live}}

title: Ruben Gallego
added: On August 7, 2008, Ruben Marinelarena changed his name to Ruben Marinelarena Gallego to honor his mother, Elisa Gallego, who raised him and his three siblings on her own after his father abandoned the family in his childhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/06/12/this-arizona-candidate-changed-his-name-his-opponent-wasnt-happy-about-it|title=This Arizona candidate changed his name. His opponent wasn't happy about it.|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref>

Gallego was married to [[Kate Gallego|Kate Widland Gallego]] (later elected [[Mayor of Phoenix]]). They divorced in 2017, just prior to the birth of their child.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2016/12/21/phoenix-vice-mayor-kate-gallego-and-rep-ruben-gallego-divorce/95721368/|title=Phoenix Vice Mayor Kate Gallego and Rep. Ruben Gallego to divorce|first=Dustin|last=Gardiner|work=The Arizona Republic |date=December 21, 2016|accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref>

Gallego currently sits on the boards of Valley Citizens League, and the President’s Community Advisory Board for [[South Mountain Community College]].<ref name=Leg>{{cite web|title=Representative Ruben Gallego|url=http://www.azleg.gov/MembersPage.asp?Member_ID=105&Legislature=50&Session_ID=102|publisher=Arizona State Legislature|accessdate=August 22, 2013}}</ref>

title: Trumpism
deleted: Journalist Elaina Plott suggests ideology is not as important as other characteristics of Trumpism.{{#tag:ref|Plott covers the Republican Party and conservatism  as a national political reporter for The New York Times. In her in-depth article on how Donald Trump has remade the Republican Party, Plott interviewed 30 or so Republican officials.|group=Note}}  She cites one political analysist (Jeff Roe) noting Trump "understood" and acted on the trend among Republican voters to be "less ideological" but "more polarized". Republicans are now more willing to accept policies like government mandated health care coverage for pre-existing conditions or trade tariffs, formerly considered burdensome government regulations by conservatives. At the same time strong avowals of support for Trump and aggressive partisanship have become part of Republican election campaigning in at least some parts of America, reaching down even to formerly collegial, issue-driven, non-partisan campaigns for local government.<ref name="Plott-27-10-2020">{{cite news |last1=Plott |first1=Elaina |title=Win or Lose, It’s Donald Trump’s Republican Party |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/27/magazine/trump-influence-gop.html |accessdate=29 October 2020 |agency=New York Times |date=27 October 2020}}</ref> Research by political scientist [[Marc Hetherington]] and others has found Trump supporters tend to share a "worldview" transcending political ideology, agreeing with statements like "the best strategy is to play hardball, even if it means being unfair". In contrast, those  who agree with statements like “cooperation is the key to success” tend to prefer (Trump adversary) [[Mitt Romney]].<ref name="Plott-27-10-2020"/>

title: Trumpism

title: Grace Napolitano
added: A 2009 story first reported by Bloomberg News<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aUZXCuqGb_Lw#|title=California's Napolitano Makes $220,000 From 1998 Campaign Loan|date=February 13, 2009 |accessdate=February 13, 2009|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> and further detailed by the Los Angeles Times<ref>{{cite web |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/14/local/me-napolitano14|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Profile: Grace Napolitano}}</ref> questioned the personal loan interest rate that the [[Federal Election Commission]] had authorized her to use during her initial 1998 run for Congress. Both Bloomberg and the Times noted that the FEC had accepted the argument that the eighteen percent rate was equivalent to the early withdrawal penalty that Napolitano was subject to by withdrawing $150,000 from her employee retirement fund and then loaning those funds to her campaign. Both sources also reported the rate dropping to ten percent in 2006, and cited FEC filings as of December 31, 2009 indicating that $221,780 in interest had been paid. ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', a Washington DC-based newspaper, reported that Federal Election Commission filings<ref>{{cite web|url=http://query.nictusa.com/cgi-bin/fecimg/?C00334706 |publisher=Federal Election Commission|accessdate=March 14, 2014|url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001634/http://query.nictusa.com/cgi-bin/fecimg/?C00334706|archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=Profile: Grace Napolitano}}</ref> for the campaign reporting period ending September 30, 2010 had indicated that the debt had been completed retired.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/1007-other/217681-report-members-of-congress-keep-money-in-the-family|title=Report: Members of Congress find ways to keep money in the family|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=April 2, 2012 |work=The Hill|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325175231/http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/1007-other/217681-report-members-of-congress-keep-money-in-the-family|archivedate=March 25, 2012}}</ref>

title: Grace Napolitano
deleted: A 2009 story first reported by Bloomberg News<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aUZXCuqGb_Lw#|title=California's Napolitano Makes $220,000 From 1998 Campaign Loan|date=February 13, 2009 |accessdate=February 13, 2009|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> and further detailed by the Los Angeles Times<ref>{{cite web |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/14/local/me-napolitano14|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Profile: Grace Napolitano}}</ref> questioned the personal loan interest rate that the [[Federal Election Commission]] had authorized her to use during her initial 1998 run for Congress.

Both Bloomberg and the Times noted that the FEC had accepted the argument that the eighteen percent rate was equivalent to the early withdrawal penalty that Napolitano was subject to by withdrawing $150,000 from her employee retirement fund and then loaning those funds to her campaign.  Both sources also reported the rate dropping to ten percent in 2006, and cited FEC filings as of December 31, 2009 indicating that $221,780 in interest had been paid. ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', a Washington DC-based newspaper, reported that Federal Election Commission filings<ref>{{cite web|url=http://query.nictusa.com/cgi-bin/fecimg/?C00334706 |publisher=Federal Election Commission|accessdate=March 14, 2014|url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001634/http://query.nictusa.com/cgi-bin/fecimg/?C00334706|archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=Profile: Grace Napolitano}}</ref> for the campaign reporting period ending September 30, 2010 had indicated that the debt had been completed retired.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/1007-other/217681-report-members-of-congress-keep-money-in-the-family|title=Report: Members of Congress find ways to keep money in the family|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=April 2, 2012 |work=The Hill|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325175231/http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/1007-other/217681-report-members-of-congress-keep-money-in-the-family|archivedate=March 25, 2012}}</ref>

In January 2011, CNN State of the Union featured Napolitano as part of a bipartisan panel alongside Republican [[Timothy F. Murphy]] to discuss adolescent mental illness in the wake of the January 8, 2011 shooting in [[Tucson, Arizona]] that resulted in the deaths of six and wounding of nineteen, including then-Arizona congresswoman [[Gabrielle Giffords]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lawmakers: Close look needed at mental health issues |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/16/lawmakers-close-look-needed-at-mental-health-issues|publisher=CNN}}</ref>

In February 2011, MSNBC's NewsNation interviewed Napolitano alongside LA Lakers basketball player [[Ron Artest]] to discuss her introduction of HR 751, the Mental Health in Schools Act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m9L7_UB7pMs|publisher=MSNBC|title=Grace Napolitano on Mental Health in Schools Act, MSNBC}}</ref>

title: 1960 United States presidential election in Idaho
added: Nixon won Idaho by 22,744 votes, or 7.6%, which was significantly less then fellow Republican [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] in [[1956 United States presidential election in Idaho|1956]], who won the state by a margin of 22.4%, or 61,111 votes. 4 years later, Democrat [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] would win the state by a margin of 1.83%, or 5,363 votes, which as of the [[2020 United States presidential election in Idaho|2020 Presidential Election]], is the last time a Democratic presidential candidate has carried the state, or even broke 40% of the total vote. Excluding Johnson's win in [[1964 United States presidential election in Idaho|1964]], as of the [[2020 United States presidential election in Idaho|2020 Presidential Election]], this is the last time a Democratic Presidential candidate got even remotely close to winning the state, as all subsequent elections after [[1964 United States presidential election in Idaho|1964]] have gone to the Republican candidate by double digits.

title: Antony Blinken
deleted: From 2009 to 2013, he served as Deputy Assistant to the President and National Security Advisor to the Vice President. In this position he also helped craft U.S. policy on [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]], and the [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iranian nuclear program]].<ref name=Columbia14>{{cite web |url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2014/december2014/blinken-2014 |title=Senate Confirms Antony "Tony" Blinken '88 as Secretary of State |author= |date=December 17, 2014 |publisher=Columbia Law |accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Sanger>{{cite news |title=Obama Makes His Choice for No. 2 Post at State Department |author=David E. Sanger |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/08/world/middleeast/antony-blinken-is-obamas-choice-for-no-2-state-department-post.html |work=The New York Times |date=November 7, 2014 |accessdate=February 3, 2015}}</ref> Of Obama's 2011 decision to [[Killing of Osama bin Laden|kill Osama bin Laden]], Blinken said "I've never seen a more courageous decision made by a leader".<ref>{{Cite book|last=Mann|first=Jim|url=https://archive.org/details/obamiansstruggle0000mann/page/313/mode/1up|title=The Obamians: The Struggle Inside the White House to Redefine American Power|date=2012|publisher=[[Viking Press]]|year=|isbn=9780670023769|location=New York|pages=313|language=English|oclc=1150993166}}</ref> A 2013 profile described him as "[o]ne of the government's key players in drafting [[Syria–United States relations|Syria policy]]",<ref>{{cite news|last1=Horowitz|first1=Jason|date=2013-09-16|title=Tony Blinken, rising|page=C1|work=[[The Washington Post]]|id={{ProQuest|1432540846}}}}</ref> for which he served as a public face.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Allen|first=Jonathan|date=2013-09-16|title=Tony Blinken's star turn|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2013/09/tony-blinkens-star-turn-096847|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-11-23|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref>

added: *<ref>{{Cite news|last=Blinken|first=Antony J.|date=2017-07-09|title=The Islamic State Is Not Dead Yet|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/09/opinion/islamic-state-mosul-iraq-strategy.html|access-date=2020-11-23|issn=0362-4331}}

title: Antony Blinken
added: He supported the U.S.–led [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]] in 2003.<ref>{{cite news |title=Joe Biden's Vote for War |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/12/us/politics/joe-biden-iraq-war.html |work=The New York Times |date=January 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Biden secretary of state pick Blinken criticized over Iraq War, consulting work |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-secretary-of-state-blinken-iraq-war-criticism |work=Fox News |date=November 23, 2020}}</ref>

Blinken supported the [[2011 military intervention in Libya]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Tony Blinken's star turn |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2013/09/tony-blinkens-star-turn-096847 |work=Politico |date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> and the [[Timber Sycamore|supply of weapons]] to [[Syrian opposition|Syrian rebels]].<ref>{{cite news |title=W.H. defends plan to arm Syrian rebels |url=https://edition.cnn.com/videos/bestoftv/2014/09/18/house-approves-aid-to-syrian-rebels-blinken-interview-newday.cnn |publisher=CNN |date=September 18, 2014}}</ref>

He condemned the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]] and expressed full support for the the democratically elected Turkish government and its institutions.<ref>{{cite news |title=US reaction to coup bid 'may have fallen short' |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/us-reaction-to-coup-bid-may-have-fallen-short/676803 |work=Anadolu Agency |date=November 2, 2016}}</ref>

In April 2015, Blinken voiced support for the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Yemen conflict: US boosts arms supplies for Saudi-led coalition |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32211550 |publisher=BBC News |date=April 7, 2015}}</ref> He said that "As part of that effort, we have expedited weapons deliveries, we have increased our intelligence sharing, and we have established a joint coordination planning cell in the Saudi operation centre."<ref>{{cite news |title=US steps up arms for Saudi campaign in Yemen |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/4/8/us-steps-up-arms-for-saudi-campaign-in-yemen |work=Al-Jazeera |date=April 8, 2015}}</ref>

Blinken described [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdoğan]]'s [[Turkey]] as a [[NATO]] ally with which the United States will have to "find ways to work more effectively together". He said the U.S. should support Turkey in its fight against the PKK, a [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict (1978–present)|Kurdish separatist]] movement deemed a terrorist organisation by Turkey.<ref name="TRT World">{{cite news |title=Who is Antony Blinken, Biden's likely pick for US Secretary of State? |url=https://www.trtworld.com/magazine/who-is-antony-blinken-biden-s-likely-pick-for-us-secretary-of-state-41727 |work=[[TRT World]] |date=November 23, 2020}}</ref>

title: Antony Blinken
added: In 2017, Blinken co-founded WestExec Advisors, a political strategy advising firm, with [[Michèle Flournoy]], Sergio Aguirre, and Nitin Chadda.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Michèle Flournoy|url=http://westexec.com/michele-flournoy/|website=WestExec Advisors|language=en|access-date=May 22, 2020|archive-date=November 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115043525/https://westexec.com/michele-flournoy/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Our Team|url=http://westexec.com/our-team/|publisher=WestExec Advisors|language=en|access-date=May 22, 2020|archive-date=May 10, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200510203137/http://westexec.com/our-team/|url-status=live}}</ref> WestExec's clients have included Google's Jigsaw, Israeli artificial-intelligence company Windward, and "''Fortune'' 100 types."<ref>{{Cite news|title=How Biden's Foreign-Policy Team Got Rich|language=en-US|work=The American Prospect|url=https://prospect.org/world/how-biden-foreign-policy-team-got-rich/|access-date=July 21, 2020|archive-date=July 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200718082955/https://prospect.org/world/how-biden-foreign-policy-team-got-rich/|url-status=live}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[The Intercept]]'', Flournoy explained WestExec seeks to employ "people recently coming out of government" with "current knowledge, expertise, contacts, networks."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Former Obama Officials Help Silicon Valley Pitch the Pentagon for Lucrative Defense Contracts|language=en-US|work=[[The Intercept]]|url=https://theintercept.com/2018/07/22/google-westexec-pentagon-defense-contracts/|access-date=May 22, 2020|archive-date=May 15, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200515133817/https://theintercept.com/2018/07/22/google-westexec-pentagon-defense-contracts/|url-status=live}}</ref>

added: === ''California v. Carlos Antonio De Bourbon Montenegro and Marcos Raul Arevalo'' ===

On November 13, two men were charged with allegedly submitting more than 8000 unlawful voter registration applications on behalf of homeless people.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Pair Charged With Voter Fraud Allegedly Submitted Thousands of Fraudulent Applications on Behalf of Homeless People|url=https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/pair-charged-with-voter-fraud-allegedly-submitted-thousands-of-fraudulent-applications-on-behalf-of-homeless-people/2464168/|access-date=2020-11-19|website=NBC Los Angeles|language=en-US}}</ref> The men, Carlos Antonio De Bourbon Montenegro, 53, and Marcos Raul Arevalo, 34, face a 41-count criminal complaint<ref name=":42">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Los Anges County Charge Sheet BA491333|url=https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/CALACOUNTY/2020/11/17/file_attachments/1603710/BA491333.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref> that included “falsifying names, addresses and signatures on nomination papers under penalty of perjury to run for mayor in the city of Hawthorne.” Montenegro is accused of planning to use his home address to collect [[Vote-by-mail in America|vote by mail ballots]] for over 8000 fictitious, non-existent, and deceased voter registrants in order to cast ballots for himself for the office of Mayor of the City of [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]] "and/or other candidates and measures."<ref name=":42" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: Prior to the election, the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] caused many states to adjust their voting rules and processes. Litigation was initiated by Democrats, seeking measures to ease voting, and Republicans seeking to block such measures.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Chaggaris|first=Steve|title=How the COVID-19 pandemic has changed the US election|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/29/how-the-pandemic-has-changed-the-u-s-election|access-date=2020-11-23|website=www.aljazeera.com|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":03">{{Cite web|last=McCoy|first=Alan Gomez and Kevin|title=Federal election lawsuits have already set a recent record. A look at 2020 in the courts.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/10/30/courts-reject-voting-rights-extensions-in-covid-shadowed-elections/5998149002/|access-date=2020-11-23|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":110">{{Cite web|title=COVID-19 and the Most Litigated Presidential Election in Recent U.S. History: How the Lawsuits Break Down|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/covid-19-most-litigated-presidential-election-in-recent-us-history/|access-date=2020-11-23|website=FRONTLINE|language=en-US}}</ref> "[M]ore than 230 election-related federal lawsuits were filed from January 1 to October 23, higher than any of the past three presidential election years during the same time period", according to a USA TODAY analysis.<ref name=":03" /> Issues related to mail-in and curbside voting, early voting, voter registration, photo ID and witness signature requirements, and voting rights for convicted felons.<ref name=":110" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: On November 25, 2020, a group of voters filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court Eastern District of Michigan against Gretchen Whitmer, the Governor of Michigan, and other state officials. The plaintiffs complain about "massive election fraud, multiple violations of Georgia laws, including O.C.G.A. §§ 21-2-30(d), 21-2-31, 21-2-33.1 and §21-2-522, and multiple Constitutional violations". The plaintiffs claimed fraudulent activities including "ballot stuffing", electronic fraud using the Dominion Voting machines. Additionally, the plaintiffs also claimed procedural violations such as failures in tallying (failed to verify signatures, check security envelopes, or properly audit election results). As the result, the plaintiffs sought to 1) have the state de-certify the election results; 2) preventing the Governor from transmitting the currently certified election results to the Electoral College; 3) have Governor Kemp transmit certified election results that state that President Donald Trump is the winner of the state election; among other reliefs <ref name="Case 2:20-cv-13134-LVP-RSW">{{cite web |url=https://defendingtherepublic.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Michigan-Complaint.pdf |accessdate=November 25, 2020 |date=November 25, 2020}}</ref>

Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
deleted: ==== ''Donald J. Trump for President v. Way'' ====

In August 2020, the Trump campaign sued New Jersey state officials in federal court, seeking to overturn an executive order issued by governor [[Phil Murphy|Phillip Murphy]]. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Murphy had ordered that mail-in ballots should be sent to all active voters in the state. The Trump campaign argued that the order violates the U.S. Constitution, which gives power to state legislatures to conduct congressional elections and select electors for the U.S. Presidency. Thereafter, the New Jersey state legislature enacted legislation to the same effect as the governor's order. In September, the Trump campaign asked U.S. District Judge Michael Shipp to prohibit vote counting before election day, and the counting of mail-in ballots that are not postmarked and received after election day. On October 6, Judge Shipp denied the request.<ref name=":21" />

deleted: Throughout 2020, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] issued at least a dozen orders related to the 2020 primary and general elections.<ref name=":04">{{Cite web|title=Supreme Court referees spate of election battles: What their decisions say about how elections are regulated|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/supreme-court-orders-2020-election-battles/|date=October 30, 2020|first=Melissa|last=Quinn|access-date=2020-11-23|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en-US|archive-date=November 24, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201124081147/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/supreme-court-orders-2020-election-battles/|url-status=live}}</ref> The court's conservative justices have objected to last-minute changes to elections that are ordered by federal judges, saying the power to administer elections lies solely with state legislatures;<ref name=":04" /><ref name=":111">{{Cite web|last=Kilgore|first=Ed|date=2020-10-29|title=How the Supreme Court Has Already Tinkered With the 2020 Election|url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/how-the-supreme-court-has-affected-voting-rules-this-year.html|access-date=2020-11-23|website=Intelligencer|language=en-us|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118062145/https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/how-the-supreme-court-has-affected-voting-rules-this-year.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-10-29 |title=Supreme Court issues flurry of last-minute election orders |url=https://apnews.com/article/supreme-court-election-orders-4820caf0f0e8a7aaa3488f242b633cdf |first=Mark |last=Sherman |access-date=2020-11-23 |website=AP News |archive-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120001817/https://apnews.com/article/supreme-court-election-orders-4820caf0f0e8a7aaa3488f242b633cdf |url-status=live }}</ref> the court's liberal justices have favored the loosening of election rules. The deciding vote has often fallen to [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Roberts]], according to [[Jonathan H. Adler|Jonathan Adler]], a professor at the [[Case Western Reserve University School of Law]].<ref name=":04" /> Under Roberts, the court has focused on keeping federal courts out of state elections, and has consistently treated election changes made by state judges or officials more leniently than those made by federal courts.<ref name=":111" />

title: Brendan Boyle
deleted: As a Democratic Congressman and due to his roots as the son of an Irish immigrant, Brendan Boyle is a keen supporter of the Good Friday Peace Agreement and in November 2020 declared his support for the continuity of the agreement above all else. Whilst his principles were judged to be highly sound, the methods he used to achieve this were deemed somewhat questionable since Boyle used the leverage of a potential free trade agreement with the United States to encourage Great Britain to water down 'Brexit' (Britain's exit from the EU) in effect reinstating all clauses of the withdrawal agreement which rendered Britain under European control to a large extent. When this information came to public knowledge this unfortunately caused a degree of outrage amongst the people in Great Britain, who judged that this stance did not allow them to become a sovereign nation once again. More significantly this stance caused some damage to the decades old 'special relationship' between the US and Great Britain in the process. Despite his threat, there remained major support for the (* yet to be declared) Democratic 'President Elect' Joe Biden in Great Britain at the time, due to widespread knowledge of his assistance during the Falklands war almost 40 years earlier.

title: Mitch McConnell
deleted: A 2012 poll and a 2016 poll each found that McConnell had the lowest home-state approval rating of any sitting senator.<ref name=Smart>{{cite web|magazine=Smart Politics|author=Ostermeier, Dr. Eric|title=Which States Give Their US Senators the Lowest Marks?|url=http://editions.lib.umn.edu/smartpolitics/2015/11/29/which-states-give-their-us-senators-the-lowest-marks/|date=November 29, 2015|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|author=Cirilli, Kevin|date=December 12, 2012|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2012/12/poll-the-most-unpopular-senator-084927|title=Poll: The most unpopular senator |magazine=Politico |accessdate=February 12, 2017}}</ref> With a 49% disapproval rate in 2017, McConnell had the highest disapproval rating of all senators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://members-of-congress.insidegov.com/stories/14197/least-popular-senators#25-Sen-Mitch-McConnell-R-Ky|title=The Least Popular U.S. Senators|publisher=InsideGov (Graphiq)|accessdate=June 15, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706181742/https://graphiq-stories.graphiq.com/stories/14197/least-popular-senators#25-Sen-Mitch-McConnell-R-Ky|archive-date=July 6, 2017|website=insidegov.com}}</ref>

In September 2019, the [[Morning Consult]] found that his approval rating had been underwater since the first quarter of 2017, when it was 44% positive and 47% negative. The best rating since that time was in the fourth quarter of 2018, when he had a 38% positive rating and a 47% negative rating among Kentuckians.<ref name=Morning /> At that time he was briefly not the least popular Senator, and was surpassed by Senators [[Claire McCaskill]] and [[Jeff Flake]].<ref>{{cite news|title=America's Most and Least Popular Senators: McConnell loses spot as least popular senator|date=January 10, 2019|author=Yokley, Eli|publisher=Morning Consult|url=https://morningconsult.com/2019/01/10/americas-most-and-least-popular-senators-q4-2018/|accessdate=September 2, 2019|website=morningconsult.com}}</ref> As of the second quarter of 2019, however, McConnell's ratings were 36% positive and 50% negative. He netted −56 among Democrats, +29 among Republicans, and −24 among Independents.<ref name=Morning>{{cite web|url=https://morningconsult.com/senator-rankings-q2-19-2/|title=Morning Consult's Senator Approval Rankings: Q2 2019, Senator Lookup|publisher=Morning Consult|year=2019|accessdate=September 2, 2019|website=morningconsult.com}}</ref> An average of polls by the Economist/YouGov, Politico/Morning Consult, and Harvard-Harris from the end of July through August 2019 (7/31–8/27), was 23% favorable and 48% unfavorable (−25.0 spread).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/mitch_mcconnell_favorableunfavorable-6672.html|title=Mitch McConnell: Favorable/Unfavorable|publisher=Real Clear Politics (RealClearHoldings, LLC.)|accessdate=September 2, 2019|website=realclearpolitics.com}}</ref>

In 2020, according to [[Morning Consult]], [[Susan Collins]] edged out McConnell as the most unpopular senator with a 52% unfavorable rating from Maine voters compared to 50% unfavorable for McConnell.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/01/16/susan-collins-approval-rating/4495142002/|title=Susan Collins surpasses Mitch McConnell as the most unpopular senator in a new poll|author=Behrmann, Savannah|date=January 17, 2020|accessdate=January 17, 2020|publisher=USA Today (Gannett)}}</ref>
