The originally-planned Charlotte convention had been awarded this status.<ref>{{cite web |last=Berky |first=Rad |title=Secret Service gives update on security for 2020 RNC |url=https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/politics/rnc/secret-service-gives-update-on-security-for-2020-rnc/275-4c37fd7f-c08e-451e-a6c4-c6aa165f248c |website=wcnc.com |accessdate=15 November 2020 |date=14 November 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CDP preps responders for 2020 Republican National Convention - Center for Domestic Preparedness |url=https://cdp.dhs.gov/news-media/article/cdp-preps-responders-for-2020-republican-national-convention |website=cdp.dhs.gov |publisher=Department of Homeland Security |accessdate=15 November 2020}}</ref> The plans for a convention in Jacksonville had also been awarded this status.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Scanlan |first1=Dan |title=Jacksonville receives federal Special Security Event designation for upcoming RNC |url=https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/local/2020/07/07/jacksonville-receives-federal-special-security-event-designation-for-upcoming-rnc/41714227/ |website=The Florida Times-Union |accessdate=15 November 2020 |date=7 July 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Jacksonville approved for federal grant to pay for RNC rally security |url=https://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/politics/jacksonville-approved-federal-grant-pay-rnc-rally-security/F6CA6JDGIVDTJNFYTM4VXNAG24/ |website=WJAX |accessdate=15 November 2020 |date=6 July 2020}}</ref>

title: 2020 Republican National Convention
added: The commitee originally reported raising $44 million for the convention.<ref name="NCPolicyWatch1"/> Due to the majority of the event being shifted away from Charlotte, the Charlotte host committee had millions in leftover funds which it could distribute with few restrictions.<ref name="NCPolicyWatch1">{{cite web |title=Host committee for Republican convention in Charlotte doles out millions in leftover cash with few restrictions |url=https://www.ncpolicywatch.com/2020/10/21/host-committee-for-republican-convention-in-charlotte-doles-out-millions-in-leftover-cash-with-few-restrictions/ |website=NC Policy Watch |accessdate=15 November 2020 |date=21 October 2020}}</ref> The committee originally promised in mid-August to give $3.2 million in funds to local [[nonprofits]] and community groups.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Morrill |first1=Jim |title=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/rnc-2020/article245051165.html |url=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/rnc-2020/article245051165.html |website=www.charlotteobserver.com |publisher=The Charlotte Observer |accessdate=15 November 2020 |date=21 August 2020}}</ref> However, by October, they had only distributed under $400,000 in funds.<ref name="NCPolicyWatch1"/>

title: 2018 North Carolina House of Representatives election
Ronna McDaniel
added: In June 2020, McDaniel shared a RNC video warning about extensive [[Electoral fraud|voter fraud]] in the upcoming 2020 election due to expansions of [[Postal voting in the United States|vote-by-mail]] related to the coronavirus pandemic.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Rizzo |first=Salvador |date=June 24, 2020 |title=Fact-checking the GOP's 'satirical' vote-by-mail video |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/06/24/fact-checking-gops-satirical-vote-by-mail-video/ |access-date=August 3, 2020}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' fact-checker wrote that the video "tortures the facts to create a narrative of an election about to be stolen. The illegality being satirized here is a phantom. State election officials, in many cases Republicans, are expanding vote-by-mail as a public health precaution to prevent the risk of spreading the coronavirus — not to rig the outcome."<ref name=":0" />

title: United States Electoral College
added: Congress passed the [[Electoral Count Act]] in 1887, now codified in [[Title 3 of the United States Code|Title 3, Chapter 1]] of the United States Code, establishing specific procedures for the counting of the electoral votes. The law was passed in response to the disputed [[1876 United States presidential election|1876 presidential election]], in which several states submitted competing slates of electors. Among its provisions, the law established deadlines that the states must meet when selecting their electors, resolving disputes, and when they must cast their electoral votes.<ref name=CRS/><ref>{{cite web|first=Edward-Isaac|last=Dovere|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-biden-electoral-count-act-1887/615994/|title=The Deadline That Could Hand Trump the Election|publisher=The Atlantic|date=2020-09-09|accessdate=2020-11-09}}</ref>

added: ===== Comparison of contingent election winners and popular vote =====
* 1800: [[Thomas Jefferson|Jefferson]] won with 61.4% of the popular vote; [[John Adams|Adams]] had 38.6%
* 1824: [[John Quincy Adams|Adams]] won with 30.9% of the popular vote; [[Andrew Jackson|Jackson]] had 41.4%

title: Rodney Davis (politician)
added: {{Main|2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Illinois#District 13}}

Davis ran for a fifth term, and was unopposed in the Republican primary. Londrigan ran again, and easily won the Democratic primary. Although the race was widely considered a tossup due to the close margin in 2018, Davis won reelection by nearly 10 points.<ref>https://www.wglt.org/post/how-rep-rodney-davis-won-so-handily-13th-congressional-district</ref> His larger margin of victory was attributed to both an increase in turnout from the district's Republican-leaning rural counties, and a decrease in the district's college campuses.

added: Both primaries took place on August 18, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elections.alaska.gov/Core/electioncalendar.php|title=Alaska Division of Elections|website=www.elections.alaska.gov}}</ref> The election was impacted by the revelation of recordings related to the controversial [[Pebble Mine]] project, which could adversely impact the ecosystem of [[Bristol Bay]]. title: Tim Echols
added: In 2017, Georgia Trend Magazine named Echols to the list of 100 Most Influential Georgians.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.georgiatrend.com/2017/01/02/100-most-influential-georgians-of-2017-wielding-power/}}</ref> It described Echols as, "a vocal advocate of renewable and clean energy" and mentioned his work on the Clean Energy Roadshow, an annual endeavor that began in 2010 in an effort to highlight alternative-fuel vehicles for both personal and industrial use.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://savannahceo.com/news/2020/08/commissioner-tim-echols-10th-annual-georgia-clean-energy-roadshow-goes-virtual/}}</ref>

Echols has also been noted for his organization of the "Unholy Tour," a bus tour of Atlanta's seedy areas that helps to raise awareness of the city’s unfortunate reputation as a hub for sex trafficking, particularly of minors.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/ajc-watchdog-atlanta-sex-trafficking-tour-reveals-the-hell/ckp2tU0uDGYFOpQZl6P3yM/}}</ref>

After years of expanding solar energy in Georgia, Conservatives for Clean Energy called Echols the "Solar Architect of Georgia" in a video interview. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://vimeo.com/460582240}}</ref>

title: Timeline of protests against Donald Trump
deleted: {{see also|2016 Donald Trump Las Vegas rally incident}}

* '''May 7''' – Protesters shouting "Love Trumps Hate" met Trump supporters before his second rally in [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. Many protesters outside spoke out against Trump's words and policy stances regarding women, Hispanics, and Muslims, including his plan to build a wall between the U.S. and Mexico. Later in the day, a group of protesters blocked a road near where Trump was supposed to speak, hoping to keep him from reaching the location. According to authorities, "a small number of arrests" were made.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Latest: Donald Trump protesters arrested in Washington |url=https://www.headlines-news.com/2016/05/08/1171187/the-latest-donald-trump-protesters-arrested-in-washington |work=Headlines News |agency=Associated Press |date=May 7, 2016 |accessdate=November 12, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112210112/https://www.headlines-news.com/2016/05/08/1171187/the-latest-donald-trump-protesters-arrested-in-washington |archive-date=November 12, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

* '''May 24''' – Following a rally in [[Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]], protesters began throwing rocks and bottles at police and police horses, smashed a glass door at the convention center, and burned a number of Trump signs and flags, filling the street with smoke.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/24/politics/donald-trump-albuquerque-protesters-police/index.html |title=Trump protesters smash door, break through barriers |date=May 24, 2016 |accessdate=May 25, 2016}}</ref><ref name="ParkerRocksHorsesFires">{{cite news |last1=Parker |first1=Ashley |title=Protesters Throw Rocks at Police Horses Outside Trump Rally in Albuquerque |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/25/us/protesters-throw-rocks-at-police-horses-outside-trump-rally-in-albuquerque.html?_r=0 |accessdate=May 25, 2016 |work=New York Times |date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> Video footage of the incident also showed protesters jumping on top of several police cars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2016/03/14/sheriff-david-clarke-responds-donald-trump-socialist-protester-hannity |title='This Is a Totalitarian Movement': Sheriff Clarke Responds to Trump Protester |date=March 14, 2016 |work=FOX News Insider |accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref>

* '''June 10''' – Anti-Trump protesters and Trump supporters clashed outside a rally in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. One Trump supporter was punched and several protesters were pushed to the ground by police. Five people were arrested but only one was charged.

* '''June 16''' – A photographer for the ''Dallas Advocate'' was hit on head with a rock that had been thrown from a crowd outside a [[Dallas]] rally that included both Trump supporters and protesters.<ref name="dfw">{{cite web |title=Donald Trump Speaks at Campaign Rally in Dallas |url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/politics/Trump-to-Host-Dallas-Rally-383154681.html |publisher=NBC DFW |accessdate=June 17, 2016}}</ref>

* '''June 19''' – During a rally in Las Vegas, [[Attempted assassination of2016 Donald Trump Las Vegas rally incident|Michael Sandford]], a 20-year-old British national, was arrested for assault and held in the county jail until he was arraigned in federal court and charged with "an act of violence on restricted grounds". He was accused of attempting to seize a police officer's firearm and later claiming he intended to kill Trump. A British citizen, he was in the U.S. illegally and is being held without bond.<ref name="sandford">{{cite news |last1=ClaryII |first1=Greg |title=Man tries to pull gun from officer at Trump rally |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/06/19/politics/trump-rally-gun-police-officer/ |publisher=CNN |date=June 19, 2016 |accessdate=June 19, 2016}}</ref><ref name=" British teenager arrested in Las Vegas tells police 'he wanted to kill Donald Trump'">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/20/british-teenager-arrested-in-las-vegas-tells-police-he-wanted-to/ |title=British teenager arrested in Las Vegas tells police 'he wanted to kill Donald Trump' |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=June 20, 2016 |accessdate=June 20, 2016 |author=Crilly Rob|newspaper=The Telegraph }}</ref> He has since then pleaded guilty to federal charges of being an illegal alien in possession of a firearm and disrupting an official function.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/sep/13/michael-steven-sandford-guilty-trump-shooting-attempt-las-vegas |title=British man pleads guilty to plan to shoot Trump at Las Vegas rally |date=September 13, 2016 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>

On April 16, Kim was [[World Bank presidential election, 2012|elected]] to head the World Bank; he took office on July 1.<ref>{{cite web|title=US choice Jim Yong Kim is new World Bank chief |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17735368|work=BBC News |date=April 16, 2012|accessdate=April 16, 2012}}</ref>

Kim was selected over [[Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala]], Minister of Finance of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.<ref>{{cite news |first= Patrick |last= McGroarty |title= Nigerian Receives Backing for World Bank |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304724404577297314251010818 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company|Dow Jones]] |date= 2012-03-22|accessdate=2012-03-22 }}</ref><ref>[http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/NEWS/0,,contentMDK:23151824~pagePK:64257043~piPK:437376~theSitePK:4607,00.html?cid=EXT_FBWB_D_EXT Closing of Nominations for President of World Bank]</ref> The [[African Union]] Commission supported her candidacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.vn/MF61|title=African Union Commission (AUC) Communiqué on the Candidacy of Dr. Ngo…|date=July 2, 2012|website=archive.vn}}</ref> Another candidate, former [[Colombia]] Finance Minister [[Jose Antonio Ocampo]] dropped out of the race and fully backed the election of [[Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.businessdayonline.com/NG/index.php/news/76-hot-topic/35942-ocampo-backs-okonjo-iweala-in-world-bank-race |title=Ocampo backs Okonjo-Iweala in World Bank race |date=14 April 2012 |agency=Reuters}}</ref> [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] was frequently mentioned as a possible successor to President Zoellick at the end of his term in mid-2012. Clinton expressly stated that she had no desire to hold further political office.

title: Alejandro Mayorkas
added: Mayorkas joined WilmerHale in November 2016 and resumed his representation of clients in their most significant and high-stakes litigation, internal investigations, and parallel proceedings. With his diverse experience in both the public and private sectors, Mayorkas helps companies address crises that span from the courtroom to the halls of Congress and in the public eye. Building on his experience leading the US Department of Homeland Security’s response to Ebola and Zika, Mr. Mayorkas currently leads [https://www.wilmerhale.com/en/solutions/coronavirus-task-force WilmerHale’s COVID-19 Coronavirus Task Force].

title: Political positions of Barack Obama
added: Obama's overall foreign policy philosophy has been postulated as the "[[Obama Doctrine]]" by ''[[Washington Post]]'' columnist [[E. J. Dionne]], which the columnist describes as "a form of [[political realism|realism]] unafraid to deploy American power but mindful that its use must be tempered by practical limits and a dose of self-awareness."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/15/AR2009041502902.html |title=E.J. Dionne Jr. - The Obama Doctrine in Action |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref> An op-ed article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' by [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]] identified Obama as a person having enormous respect for and being deeply influenced by the philosophy of [[Reinhold Niebuhr]].<ref name="Brooks">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/26/opinion/26brooks.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=%2522David%20Brooks%2522%20Obama%20Niebuhr&st=cse|title= Obama, Gospel and Verse|work=David Brooks|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=March 19, 2010 | date=April 26, 2007}}</ref>

Obama's [[s:Remarks of Senator Barack Obama to the Chicago Council on Global Affairs|first major speech]] on [[foreign policy]] was delivered to the [[Chicago Council on Global Affairs]] on April 23, 2007. He identified the problems that he believes the current foreign policy has caused, and the five ways the United States can lead again, focused on "common security", "common humanity", and remaining "a beacon of freedom and justice for the world":<ref>{{cite web|url=http://my.barackobama.com/page/content/fpccga/ |title=Foreign Policy Remarks at CCGA |publisher=my.barackobama.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref>
* "Bringing a responsible end" to the [[Iraq War|war in Iraq]] and refocusing on the broader region.
* "Building the first truly 21st century military and showing wisdom in how we deploy it."
* "Marshalling a global effort" to secure, destroy, and stop the spread of [[weapons of mass destruction]].
* "Rebuild and construct the alliances and partnerships necessary to meet common challenges and confront common threats," including [[global warming]].

* "Invest in our common humanity" through foreign aid and supporting the "pillars of a sustainable democracy – a strong legislature, an independent judiciary, the rule of law, a vibrant [[civil society]], a free press, and an honest police force."

During that speech, Obama called for an expansion of the [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. Armed Forces]] "by adding 65,000 soldiers to the [[United States Army|Army]] and 27,000 [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]]", an idea previously introduced by [[United States Secretary of Defense|Defense Secretary]] [[Robert Gates]].

In a Washington, D.C., speech entitled "A New Strategy for a New World"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://my.barackobama.com/page/content/newstrategy |title=A New Strategy for a New World |accessdate=July 16, 2008 |last=Obama |first=Barack |date=July 15, 2008 |publisher=Obama for America }}</ref> delivered July 15, 2008, Obama stated five main foreign policy goals:
* Ending the war in Iraq responsibly.
* Finishing the fight against al Qaeda and the Taliban.
* Securing all nuclear weapons and materials from terrorists and rogue states.
* Rebuilding US alliances to meet the challenges of the 21st century.

title: Political positions of Barack Obama
deleted: ''[[The Almanac of American Politics]] (2008)'' rated Obama's overall social policies in 2006 as more [[conservative]] than 21% of the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]], and more [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] than 77% of the Senate (18% and 77%, respectively, in 2005).<ref name=aap>{{cite book |title=Almanac of American Politics (2008)|publisher=[[National Journal]] |author=Michael Barone with Richard Cohen |page=538}}</ref>

In 2010, Obama signed the [[Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010]], which ended a policy of not allowing gays, lesbians and bisexuals to state their sexual orientation openly in the military. In May 2012, he became the first sitting U.S. president to announce his support for legalizing [[same-sex marriage]].<ref name="BBC.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18014102|title=Obama says same-sex couples should be able to marry|author=|date=May 9, 2012|work=BBC.co.uk}}</ref>

During his second [[inaugural address]] on January 21, 2013, Obama called for full equality for people who are LGBT: "Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law — for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well." This was a historic moment, being the first time that a president mentioned [[LGBT rights in the United States|gay rights]] or the word ''gay'' in an inaugural address.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robillard|first=Kevin|title=First inaugural use of the word 'gay'|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/01/first-inaugural-use-of-the-word-gay-86499.html#ixzz2Idac3ubt|accessdate=21 January 2013|publisher=Politico|date=21 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Obama Inauguration Speech Makes History With Mention Of Gay Rights Struggle, Stonewall Uprising|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/21/obama-inauguration-speech-stonewall-gays_n_2520962.html#slide=892590|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=21 January 2013|first=Noah|last=Michelson|date=January 21, 2013}}</ref>

title: Joe Manchin
deleted: On December 18, 2010, Manchin skipped the vote to repeal Don't Ask, Don't Tell and the vote on the [[DREAM Act]], regarding immigration. The [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] criticized Manchin for attending a family Christmas gathering instead of voting on these important issues. "For a Senator who has only been on the job a few weeks," commented the NRSC, "Manchin's absence today, and the apparent lack of seriousness with which he takes the job he was elected to do, speaks volumes."<ref name="Skip votes">{{cite web |title=Joe Manchin Skipped DREAM And DADT Votes For A Christmas Party |first=Jillian

|last=Rayfield |date=December 18, 2010 |website=[[Talking Points Memo]] |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/12/joe-manchin-skipped-dream-and-dadt-votes-for-a-christmas-party.php}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that he was the only Senate Democrat to miss these votes "on two of his party's signature pieces of legislation."<ref>{{cite news |title=Joe Manchin absent for two major Senate votes |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/12/joe-manchin-absent-for-dream-a.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 4, 2012 |first=Felicia |last=Sonmez |date=December 18, 2010}}</ref> Later, in 2012, Manchin also skipped the Democratic National Convention, saying he planned "to spend this fall focused on the people of West Virginia."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hamby |first1=Peter |last2=Killough |first2=Ashley |title=Manchin to skip Democratic National Convention |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/18/manchin-to-skip-democratic-national-convention/ |date=June 18, 2012 |website=Political Ticker - CNN |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>

title: Kamala Harris
added: On November 7, 2020, ''[[CBC News]]'' interviewed Wanda Kagan, a high school friend of Kamala.<ref name=Cbc2020-11-07/>  She described Kamala as her best friend, and described how she confided in her that she was being molested by her stepfather.  She said that Kamala told her mother who then insisted she come to live with them, for the remainder of her final year of high school.  She said Kamala had recently told her that their friendship, and playing a role in countering Wanda's exploitation, helped form the commitment she felt in protecting women and children, when she was a prosecutor.

title: 2020 United States Senate election in Colorado
2020 United States Senate election in Colorado
2020 United States Senate election in Colorado
2020 United States Senate election in Colorado
added: The election was not close with Hickenlooper winning by 9.3%, with still 3% left to be counted. Hickenlooper's win was expected, as [[Colorado]] has moved more toward being a blue state. Key to Hickenlooper's victory was [[Denver County]] home of [[Denver]], and [[Denver]]'s suburban counties, Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, and Jefferson. Gardner did do well in the typically red [[El Paso County]] home of [[Colorado Springs]]. Gardner also did well in many rural areas of the state. However, Hickenlooper's strong performance in heavily populated counties proved too much for Gardner to overcome. Hickenlooper was also likely helped by now President-Elect [[Joseph R. Biden]] who won the Centennial State by 13.5%. Hickenlooper will be the first senator from [[Colorado]] who was also the [[Governor of Colorado]] since Senator [[Edwin Johnson]] was elected in 1936. Senator-Elect Hickenlooper will be sworn in on January 3, 2021 for a six year term that expires on January 3, 2027.

title: Spotify
deleted: Spotify offers advertisers ten different types of advertising formats, described in 2016 as: Branded Moments, Sponsored Playlists, Sponsored Sessions, Video Takeovers, Audio, Display, Overlay, Homepage Takeovers, Branded Playlists, and Advertiser Pages. These advertisements vary in size, type and user engagement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/formats/|title=Formats|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219072547/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/formats/|archivedate=19 December 2016}}</ref>

* Branded Moments allow brands to "tell their story over a series of sequential displays with 100% share-of-voice during the 30-minute session" by using "an immersive vertical video" and can unlock 30 minutes of uninterrupted music.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/branded-moments/|title=Branded Moments|publisher=Spotify|access-date=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220134032/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/branded-moments/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Sponsored Playlist is an "exclusive one week sponsorship of Spotify’s top owned & operated playlists".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/sponsored-playlist/|title=Sponsored Playlist|publisher=Spotify|access-date=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220134035/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/sponsored-playlist/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Sponsored Sessions allow brands to "offer their audience uninterrupted listening in exchange for a video view". They are only available on mobile and tablet devices and are limited to select markets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/sponsored-session/|title=Sponsored Session|publisher=Spotify|access-date=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220134624/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/sponsored-session/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Video Takeover is a "video spot with a companion display unit", is "served during commercial ad breaks between songs in a music session", and is only available on the computer apps.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/video-takeover/|title=Video Takeover|publisher=Spotify|access-date=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220134538/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/video-takeover/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Audio Ads are "served during commercial ad breaks between songs in a music session" with a maximum duration of 30 seconds and play every 15 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/audio/|title=Audio|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220135642/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/audio/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Display Ads are "clickable images displayed for 30 seconds". Display ads are shown at the bottom of the Spotify client.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/display/|title=Display|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220135233/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/display/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Overlay is "Spotify's 'welcome back' ad. It greets returning users on mobile and desktop with a can't-be-missed, large display ad to maximize brand impact and performance".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/overlay/|title=Overlay|publisher=Spotify|access-date=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220134714/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/overlay/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Homepage Takeovers are "a combination of background skin and optional interactive area that takes over the Spotify homepage".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/homepage-takeover/|title=Homepage Takeover|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220133939/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/homepage-takeover/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Branded Playlists are "Spotify playlists that contain a branded cover art image and text". They can only have one song per artist, and must have a minimum of 20 tracks in the playlist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/branded-playlist/|title=Branded Playlists|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220135143/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/branded-playlist/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

* Advertiser Pages are a "microsite seamlessly integrated into the Spotify player", that can "contain practically any content you'd find on a webpage, including videos, clickable images, blogs, news, links, and comments."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/advertiser-page/|title=Advertiser Page|publisher=Spotify|accessdate=16 December 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220133853/https://spotifyforbrands.com/us/format/advertiser-page/|archivedate=20 December 2016}}</ref>

In January 2020, Spotify launched its own Streaming Ad Insertion technology (SAI) that inserts ads into podcasts as people listen. Ad choice adapts based on the user's profile and location data. These ads still play for Premium account subscribers and the company has announced plans to expand podcast ad units with interactive elements. <ref>{{Cite web|last=Carman|first=Ashley|date=2020-06-22|title=Spotify is testing interactive podcast ads so you never have to remember a promo code again|url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/22/21295859/spotify-interactive-ads-podcasts-in-app-offer-launch|access-date=2020-11-03|website=The Verge|language=en}}</ref>

title: Greg Casar
added: Gregorio Casar was born in [[Houston]], Texas to Mexican immigrants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austintexas.gov/department/council-member-gregorio-casar-biography|title=Council Member Gregorio Casar - Biography |author=<!--Not stated--> ||website= City of Austin |publisher= City of Austin|access-date=May 21, 2019}}</ref> He attended Strake Jesuit College Prep for high school, where he ran track.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chron.com/neighborhood/bellaire/sports/article/Strake-Jesuit-runner-gives-it-his-all-in-state-9578554.php |title=Strake Jesuit runner gives it his all in state finale |last=Hamilton |first=Heath |date=May 15, 2007 |website=www.chron.com |publisher=Houston Chronicle |access-date=May 21, 2019}}</ref> He attended college at the [[University of Virginia]], where he graduated with a degree in Bachelors of Arts in Political and Social Thought in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kvue.com/article/news/politics/austin-city-council-district-4-election-meet-greg-casar/341814786 |title=Austin City Council District 4 Election: Meet Greg Casar |last=Goudeau |first=Ashley |date=October 27, 2016 |publisher=KVUE |access-date=May 21, 2019}}</ref> Casar began his activism in college, organizing with Students and Workers United for a Living Wage, which led the campaign to get University administration to pay all of its workers a higher living wage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.c-ville.com/Living_Wagers_hopeful_new_administration_means_fair_wages/ |title=Living Wagers hope new administration means fair wages|last=Canzi |first=Chiara |date=September 28, 2010 |publisher=C-VILLE |access-date=May 21, 2019}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Indiana
2020 United States presidential election in Indiana
deleted: Indiana is a reliably [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] state, despite it narrowly voting for [[Barack Obama]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Cohen|first=Micah|date=2012-10-19|title=After Brief Role as Battleground, Indiana Exits, Stage Right|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/after-brief-role-as-battleground-indiana-exits-stage-right/|access-date=2020-11-09|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US}}</ref> Indiana’s population is [[Retirement plans in the United States|older]], [[White Americans|whiter]], and less [[Education in the United States|educated]] than the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] at-large. Per [[Exit poll|exit polls]] by the [[Associated Press|Associate Press]], Trump’s strength in Indiana came from [[White people|whites]] without a [[Academic degree|college degree]], who supported the President 67%. This result included 82% among white [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] or white [[Born again|born-again]] [[Christians]]. A 57% majority believed Trump was better able to [[Trump trade war|handle]] [[Foreign trade of the United States|international trade]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|date=2020-11-03|title=Indiana Voter Surveys: How Different Groups Voted|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/11/03/us/elections/ap-polls-indiana.html|access-date=2020-11-09|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Bill Seitz
added: On January 24, 2018, the website [https://web.archive.org/web/20181208190906/https://www.3rdrailpolitics.com/#top 3rd Rail Politics] reported Republican legislators' alleged sexist and demeaning comments toward women at a roast for outgoing Ohio House Speaker [[Cliff Rosenberger]]'s chief of staff [[Mike Dittoe]]. Held at the Athletic Club of Columbus just down the street from the Capital Building, the event was attended by legislators, lobbyists and campaign contributors.

"Representative William Seitz (R-Cincinnati) called out former Rep. Diana Fessler, calling her a nutjob who "wore a tin foil hat."  More demeaning still, he compared her to his current Southwest Ohio colleague Rep. [[Candice Keller]]. Saving the best for last, he imagined certain legislators doing their work "set to music."  Former Senator [[Cliff Hite]], who as first reported by 3rd Rail was drummed out of office for disturbing allegations of harassing a female statehouse staffer, could have [[Marvin Gaye]]'s "Let's Get It on," Seitz joked.  "Or better yet," he added, "The Answer is Blowing in the Wind." Not content to just smack one chamber, he added a similar off-color double entendre to describe the song for former Rep. [[Wes Goodman]].  [Not suitable for print].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.3rdrailpolitics.com/article/906 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-12-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181215224437/https://www.3rdrailpolitics.com/article/906 |archive-date=2018-12-15 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
These remarks took place the same week House members received sexual harassment training mandated as a result of recent local and national scandals.

Days later, Seitz apologized for the remarks, calling them "irresponsible". Ohio Speaker Cliff Rosenberger, in a statement, said he expects Seitz to be "more thoughtful" and "more respectful" in the future.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.journal-news.com/news/state-lawmaker-apologizes-for-comments-reportedly-made-roast/4vyp1sXF3mSOND5gA8Xe2N/|title=Ohio House leadership member apologizes for comments during roast that made a local lawmaker ‘livid’|first=Staff Writer|last=Michael D. Pitman|website=journal-news}}</ref>

State Reps. [[Nickie Antonio]], [[Teresa Fedor]] and [[Michele Lepore-Hagan]] and [[Kathleen Clyde]] told Republican House Speaker Clifford Rosenberger that Seitz should resign, a move Seitz called "politically motivated".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sunny95.com/news/061160-061160-4-in-ohio-house-want-lawmaker-to-resign-over-crass-remarks/|title=4 in Ohio House want lawmaker to resign over crass remarks}}</ref>

Soon after, an anonymous woman filed a complaint, stating that Seitz's remarks worsened an already hostile working environment in the Statehouse. Republican Attorney General [[Mike Dewine]] paid $12,000 to Taft Stettinius & Hollister to conduct an internal investigation. Taft Stettinius and Hollister not only gave Dewine substantial campaign contributions, the firm employed Seitz  for over 3 decades. Taft's investigators conducted only three interviews - of Seitz and two witnesses - then concluded Seitz had not violated the House's Sexual Harassment Policies. The review appeared to exclude any witnesses that were offended Seitz's remarks, or any victims of Statehouse sexual harassment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cleveland.com/open/2018/06/rep_bill_seitz_cleared_of_sexu.html|title=Rep. Bill Seitz cleared of sexual harassment after investigation by his former firm|first=Associated|last=Press|date=June 15, 2018|website=cleveland}}</ref>

The Toledo Blade called for second investigation "with no [[conflict of interest]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.toledoblade.com/opinion/editorials/2018/06/20/Re-do-the-review-of-Bill-Seitz/stories/20180620207|title=Re-do the review of Bill Seitz|website=Toledo Blade}}</ref>

Rep. [[Michele Lepore-Hagan]] said, "...interviewing only two of the more than 100 people who attended the event where Rep. Seitz degraded women, and then burying the report makes it clear that the leadership of the House and AG DeWine wanted to whitewash this particular incident".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohiohouse.gov/democrats/press/ohio-ag-picked-donor-to-whitewash-sexual-harassment-investigation-of-gop-lawmaker-lawmaker-says|title=Ohio AG Picked Donor To Whitewash Sexual Harassment Investigation Of GOP Lawmaker, Lawmaker Says|website=www.ohiohouse.gov}}</ref>

State Reps. [[Teresa Fedor]] (D-Toledo) and [[Nickie J. Antonio]] (D-Lakewood) asked Ohio Attorney General (AG) Mike DeWine to hire an objective third party to reopen the harassment investigation of Rep. Bill Seitz (R-Cincinnati).<ref>http://www.ohiohouse.gov/nickie-j-antonio/press/ohio-ag-needs-to-open-independent-harassment-investigation-of-bill-seitz-lawmakers-say</ref>

An ethics grievance was filed with the Ohio Supreme Court against firm partner Stuart Dornette, regarding the firm's failure to disclose this conflict of interest. Dornette has contributed to Seitz's political campaigns. Seitz referred to the complainant as a "knucklehead" <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2018/06/25/taft-law-firm-shouldve-disclosed-conflict-interest-grievance-says/732404002/|title=Taft law firm should have disclosed conflict of interest, grievance says|first=Chrissie|last=Thompson|website=Cincinnati.com}}</ref>

deleted: Sectarianism was relatively low compared to periods of the Ottoman Empire and what is seen from Turkey in the 1980s. President İnönü was a hardline Kemalist who wanted to continue the policy of Ataturk. This meant religious freedom was guaranteed to all Turkish citizens. As such, Alevis, Christians and Jews lived in harmony with the Sunni majority, unlike anything that was seen before. Ataturk demanded national unity and İnönü would continue to fight for it even after losing power.

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Florida
added: [[United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit]], located in [[Atlanta]], ruled that ex-felons could not vote in Florida unless they pay fines and fees. Florida voters approved amendment 4 in November 2018, which restored voting for felons upon completion of all terms of sentence including parole or probation, except for those who committed murders or were involved in sex-crimes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/initiatives/initdetail.asp?account=64388&seqnum=1|title=Initiative Information|website=Florida Division of Elections |access-date=September 26, 2018}}</ref> The Republican-controlled legislature then passed a law which required ex-felons to settle their financial obligation in courts. United States District Court in Tallahassee ruled against it in May, but the circuit court overturned it in September, which may create further problems for ex-felons to exercise their voting rights in November. Civil rights organizations including [[American Civil Liberties Union]] opposed the decision by the court.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/11/us/trump-vs-biden</ref>

title: List of United States senators from South Carolina
Brad Raffensperger
deleted: During the [[2020 Georgia (U.S. state) elections|2020 Georgia elections]], Raffensperger sought to prevent Georgia polling places from printing paper backups of voter registration and absentee voting information in case polling places would struggle to use voter check-in tablets, called Poll Pads, which had been problematic in Georgia's primary elections earlier that year. The tablets had caused long lines at polling places. Voting rights groups had requested paper backups to prevent a risk of chaos on election day in case the tablets failed.<ref name=AppealsCt>{{Cite web|last=Niesse|first=Mark|newspaper=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|title=Appeals court stops more paper backups of Georgia voter records|url=https://www.ajc.com/politics/appeals-court-stops-more-paper-backups-of-georgia-voter-records/OPHIW2T2RJHUJGIARWZSZKYTLU/|date=October 24, 2020}}</ref> The voting rights groups sued Raffensperger in federal court; they obtained an order from a [[United States district judge|district judge]] ordering Georgia election officials to prepare such paper backups, but this order was blocked by the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit]].<ref name=AppealsCt/>

title: Brad Raffensperger
added: During the [[2020 Georgia (U.S. state) elections|2020 Georgia elections]], Raffensperger sought to prevent Georgia polling places from printing paper backups of voter registration and absentee voting information in case polling places would struggle to use voter check-in tablets, called Poll Pads, which had been problematic in Georgia's primary elections earlier that year. The tablets had caused long lines at polling places. Voting rights groups had requested paper backups to prevent a risk of chaos on election day in case the tablets failed.<ref name=AppealsCt>{{Cite web|last=Niesse|first=Mark|newspaper=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|title=Appeals court stops more paper backups of Georgia voter records|url=https://www.ajc.com/politics/appeals-court-stops-more-paper-backups-of-georgia-voter-records/OPHIW2T2RJHUJGIARWZSZKYTLU/|date=October 24, 2020}}</ref> The voting rights groups sued Raffensperger in federal court; they obtained an order from a [[United States district judge|district judge]] ordering Georgia election officials to prepare such paper backups, but this order was blocked by the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit]].<ref name=AppealsCt/>

In the 2020 election, Democratic presidential candidate [[Joe Biden]] became [[president-elect of the United States|president-elect]], defeating incumbent [[Donald Trump]], and Democrats made gains in Georgia, with Biden appearing to be on track to [[2020 United States presidential election in Georgia|win the state]], the first time since 1992 that a Democratic presidential nominee had won Georgia.<ref name=PoliticoCall>{{Cite web|author=Marianne LeVine & James Arkin|title=Loeffler, Perdue call on Georgia's Republican secretary of state to resign|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/09/loeffler-perdue-georgia-secretary-state-resign-435484|date=November 9, 2020|website=Politico}}</ref><ref name=AJCCall>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ajc.com/politics/georgias-senators-seek-secretary-of-states-resignation-over-election/A3JUFWTWORDH7LTL2XSZ7ODWPA/|newspaper=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|title=Citing no evidence, Georgia’s U.S. senators demand elections head resign|first1=Mark|last1=Niesse|first2=Greg|last2=Bluestein|date=November 10, 2020}}</ref> After the election, Raffensperger's fellow Republicans, Georgia's U.S. Senators [[David Perdue]] and [[Kelly Loeffler]] issued a joint statement accusing Raffensperger of unspecified "failures" and calling for him to resign.<ref name=PoliticoCall/><ref name=AJCCall/> Perdue and Loeffler offered no evidence in support of their claims.<ref name=PoliticoCall/><ref name=AJCCall/> State elections officials and other Republican leaders noted that there was no evidence of wrongdoing in connection with the election.<ref name=AJCCall/> Both Perdue and Loeffler were up for re-election but failed to achieve a majority of the vote, triggering a [[runoff election]] in Georgia against their Democratic opponents, which is set to take place on January 5, 2021, and will determine party control of the Senate.<ref name=PoliticoCall/><ref name=AJCCall/> Raffensperger rejected the calls for his resignation, saying, "As a Republican, I am concerned about Republicans keeping the U.S. Senate. I recommend that Senators Loeffler and Perdue start focusing on that."<ref name=PoliticoCall/> Raffensperger added, "If I was Senator Perdue, I'd be irritated I was in a runoff. And both Senators and I are all unhappy with the potential outcome for our President. But I am the duly elected Secretary of State. One of my duties involves helping to run elections for all Georgia voters. I have taken that oath, and I will execute that duty and follow Georgia law."<ref name=AJCCall/>

title: Brad Raffensperger
added: In the state House, Raffensperger sponsored legislation to bar county officials from personally profiting from [[tax lien]]s. Previously, the [[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton County]] tax commissioner personally received fees from tax liens and sales of tax liens to a private collection companies collecting $200,000 over a four-year period; the legislation ended the self-enrichment practice.<ref>[https://www.ajc.com/news/local-govt--politics/stops-fulton-tax-commissioner-arthur-ferdinand-fee-liens/IPNKq03DAKVpfesDXgLq1K/ Ga. stops Fulton Tax Commissioner Arthur Ferdinand's fee on liens], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (March 23, 2017).</ref> Raffensperger also sponsored a measure to amend the [[Georgia Constitution|Georgia state constitution]] to allow the re-creation of a county that previously existed but had later merged with another county; the measure would allow northern Fulton County to split off to form [[Milton County, Georgia|Milton County]].<ref>[https://www.ajc.com/news/local-govt--politics/milton-county-legislation-the-table-again/t5c0GAfyPsmG8xF19VQPQI/ Milton County legislation on the table again], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (August 28, 2016).</ref>

Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act
added: In October 2020 President [[Donald Trump]] by Executive Order created a [[Schedule F appointment|Schedule F classification]] category, which according to Donald Kettl, the Sid Richardson professor at the University of Texas at Austin’s Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs: “It wants to undo what the Pendleton Act and subsequent civil service laws tried to accomplish, which was to create a career civil service with expertise that is both accountable to elected officials but also a repository of expertise in government. The argument here is that anyone involved in policymaking can be swept into this new classification, and once they’re in they’re subject to political review and dismissal for any reason.”<ref> [https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/10/stunning-executive-order-would-politicize-civil-service/169479/ ‘Stunning’ Executive Order Would Politicize Civil Service]</ref>

title: Rob Portman
deleted: During his tenure in [[United States House of Representatives|Congress]], Portman authored or co-authored over a dozen bills that became law,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/person.xpd?id=400325|title=Robert Portman, former U.S. Representative|publisher=GovTrack.us|accessdate=August 21, 2010}}</ref> including legislation to [[Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998|reform the Internal Revenue Service]], curb [[unfunded mandates]], and expand [[pensions]].<ref>[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s104-1 Senate 1: Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995], ''GovTrack.us''. Retrieved October 17, 2009.</ref> Portman also co-authored legislation to swap [[Costa Rica]]'s debt for the preservation of tropical forests.<ref>[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/108/hr4654 H.R. 4654 To reauthorize the Tropical Forest Conservation Act of 1998], "GovTrack.us". Retrieved April 11, 2012.</ref> He published an article called "Addicted to Failure" in the congressional ''Policy Review'' in autumn 1996.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/bibdisplay.pl?index=p000449|title=Addicted to Failure |publisher=Policy Review, 79|date=September–October 1996|accessdate=December 15, 2012}}</ref> In the article, Portman writes: {{cquote| President Clinton hurt the antidrug effort by cutting the Office of National Drug Control policy from 147 to 25 full-time positions, by hiring a [[Surgeon General of the United States|surgeon general]] who advocated legalization of drugs, by cutting funding for interdiction efforts, and by sending confusing messages about the stigma of illegal drug use. It is no surprise, then, that after dramatic reductions in drug use during the decade before Clinton took office, drug use has nearly doubled among teenagers during his [[Clinton Administration|administration]]. ... The public rightly expects the federal government to do something about drug abuse, which diminishes and threatens the lives of so many of our young people. And the federal government clearly has an important role in combating drug abuse: protecting our borders and interdicting drugs from other countries, strengthening our federal criminal-justice system, and providing federal assistance for the best prevention and treatment programs. ... Despite a significant federal effort, however, our country is still seeing dramatic increases in drug use among our teenagers. In the last two years alone, use of drugs has increased 50 percent. We need a new approach.<ref name="Portman">{{cite news |last=Portman|first=Rob |title=Addicted to Failure |url= http://www.unz.org/Pub/PolicyRev-1996sep-00056 |date=September 1996|work=Policy Review |accessdate=April 1, 2013 }}</ref>}}

title: Greg Gianforte
added: On January 20, 2016, Gianforte announced his candidacy for the Republican Party's nomination for [[Governor of Montana]] in the 2016 election.<ref name="Lutey2016">{{cite web |url=http://billingsgazette.com/article_6f4b00b1-a6c8-57dd-9e91-25d5c6235150.html |title=Gianforte declares candidacy for governor in Billings |work=Billings Gazette |date=January 20, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019134329/http://billingsgazette.com/article_6f4b00b1-a6c8-57dd-9e91-25d5c6235150.html |archive-date=October 19, 2016 |url-status=live |first=Tom |last=Lutey |issn=2372-868X |access-date=January 20, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A citizen of [[Butte, Montana|Butte]] filed a political practices complaint against Gianforte alleging that he began campaigning before registering; the complaint was dismissed.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Political practices complaint filed against Gianforte |url=http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/politics/political-practices-complaint-filed-against-gianforte/article_1650b52f-2c1c-55eb-bc6a-e1fa101addf4.html |accessdate=August 29, 2015 |first=Troy |last=Carter}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Complaint alleges that Gianforte campaigned before registering as a candidate |url=http://www.kxlh.com/story/29911418/complaint-alleges-that-gianforte-campaigned-before-registering-as-a-candidate |accessdate=August 29, 2015 |first=Sanjay |last=Talwani |work=MTN News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150901002610/http://www.kxlh.com/story/29911418/complaint-alleges-that-gianforte-campaigned-before-registering-as-a-candidate |archive-date=September 1, 2015 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Troy|title=Campaign Complaint Against Gianforte Dismissed|url=http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/politics/campaign-complaint-against-gianforte-dismissed/article_fc53793c-47f0-5230-a45e-f93365bad3a6.html|newspaper=Bozeman Daily Chronicle|accessdate=January 28, 2016}}</ref>

In a campaign speech that year, Gianforte stated that he had been involved in discussions with [[Facebook]] about bringing a new call center to Montana, but that Facebook had declined because of that state's business equipment tax.<ref>Phil Drake, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/local/2016/04/18/gianforte-unveils-tax-relief-plan/83202158/ Gianforte unveils '406 Tax Relief' plan], ''Great Falls Tribune'' (April 18, 2016).</ref> A Facebook spokesman disputed Gianforte's claims, saying that no discussions with Gianforte had taken place and that the tax was not the reason the company decided not to locate a call center in Montana. Gianforte stood by his statement saying that he had spoken with a Facebook executive the previous fall.<ref>Associated Press, [http://kopr94.net/facebook-disputes-montana-candidates-claim/ Facebook disputes claims of Montana candidate] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402233624/http://kopr94.net/facebook-disputes-montana-candidates-claim/ |date=April 2, 2017 }} (April 21, 2016).</ref>

During his gubernatorial campaign, Gianforte pledged not to accept special interest PAC money and ran television ads criticizing his opponent for doing so.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/montanas-greg-gianforte-ditches-no-pac-pledge-2018|title=Montana's Greg Gianforte Ditches 'No PAC' Pledge for 2018|work=Roll Call Newspaper|last=Pathe|first=Simone|date= February 7, 2018|accessdate= February 7, 2018}}</ref> He came under scrutiny when an audio tape surfaced revealing his past advocacy to replace state income tax and state business tax revenue with a state sales tax.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/gianforte-s-sales-tax-testimony-is-subject-of-dems-attack/article_6d06d398-1e54-58dd-afe6-1c19e655138f.html|title=Gianforte's sales tax testimony is subject of Dems attack|work=Billings Gazette|last=Michels|first=Holly|date=4 November 2016|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://billingsgazette.com/news/local/software-ceo-calls-income-tax-harmful/article_2ba8bab6-a1ae-55c3-aa1c-c146648fd9f7.html|title=Software CEO calls income tax harmful|work=Billings Gazette|last=Johnson|first=Charles|date=May 30, 2002|accessdate=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtpr.org/post/sales-tax-has-little-support-despite-montanas-budget-woes|title=Sales Tax Has Little Support Despite Montana's Budget Woes|work=Montana Public Radio|last=O'Brien|first=Edward|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>

Management of public lands was a point of contention in Gianforte's 2016 campaign for governor.<ref name="Fraser">Jayme Fraser, [http://missoulian.com/news/state-and-regional/bullock-gianforte-spar-over-access-to-public-lands/article_cda4f862-a9e2-559f-b2d7-91bc497d8d4c.html Bullock, Gianforte spar over access to public lands], Missourian (July 22, 2016).</ref> In 2009, Gianforte's [[Limited liability company|LLC]] filed a lawsuit against the [[Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks]] about the boundaries of an easement for public access to the East Gallatin River adjacent to his property.<ref name="FraserMichels">Hayme Fraser & Holly Michels, [http://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/governor-candidate-gianforte-sued-state-in-over-access-to-river/article_951b0234-304c-5570-b90e-83e92fb8c976.html Governor candidate Gianforte sued state in 2009 over access to river], ''Billings Gazette'', May 10, 2016.</ref> Gianforte's suit against the state became an issue in the 2016 campaign with Gianforte's critics characterizing it as a wealthy out-of-stater's effort to block public access to a popular stream.<ref name="Fraser"/><ref name="FraserMichels" /><ref name="Kuglin"/> Gianforte consistently denied the allegations and called the issue a misunderstanding, noting the suit was never served, though the lawsuit was settled outside of court.<ref name="Fraser"/> Gianforte opposes [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]].<ref name=":1"/> He opposes [[abortion]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ktvq.com/story/33501881/mt-govs-race-features-big-difference-on-social-issues-but-gianforte-says-not-that-relevant|title=MT gov's race features big difference on social issues – but Gianforte says it's not that relevant|last=Dennison|first=Mike|publisher=MNT News (KTVH)|date=October 27, 2016|access-date=April 10, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170411135132/http://www.ktvq.com/story/33501881/mt-govs-race-features-big-difference-on-social-issues-but-gianforte-says-not-that-relevant|archive-date=April 11, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/steve-bullock-vs-greg-gianforte-nonpartisan-candidate_us_580ecdf8e4b0f871578a0008|title=Steve Bullock vs. Greg Gianforte: Nonpartisan Candidate Guide For 2016 Montana Governor's Race|last=Project|first=Campus Election Engagement|date=October 25, 2016|website=Huffington Post|access-date=April 10, 2017}}</ref>

[[Steve Bullock (American politician)|Steve Bullock]], the incumbent Democratic governor, defeated Gianforte in the November general election, 50%–46%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sos.mt.gov/Portals/142/Elections/archives/2010s/2016/2016GeneralStatewideCanvass.pdf|title=2016 Statewide General Election Canvass|publisher=Montana Secretary of State}}</ref>

title: Mike Pompeo
added: In the aftermath of the [[2020 United States presidential election]] amid legal challenges pursued by the Trump administration, Pompeo, when questioned whether there would be a 'smooth transition' into a [[Joe Biden|Biden]] administration, responded, "[t]here will be a smooth transition to a second Trump administration".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-2020-election-results/2020/11/10/933516479/pompeo-promises-a-smooth-transition-to-a-second-trump-administration|title=Pompeo Promises 'A Smooth Transition To A Second Trump Administration'|first=Bill|last=Chappell|work=[[NPR]]|date=November 10, 2020|access-date=November 11, 2020}}</ref>

title: Janet Yellen
added: On February 2, 2018, the [[Brookings Institution]] announced that Yellen would be joining the think tank as a Distinguished Fellow in Residence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2018/02/02/welcome-to-brookings-chair-yellen/|title=Welcome to Brookings, Chair Yellen|last=Wessel|first=David|date=2018-02-02|work=Brookings|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|archive-date=February 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202185313/https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2018/02/02/welcome-to-brookings-chair-yellen/|url-status=live}}</ref> She will be affiliated with the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy, joining her predecessor and former Federal Reserve Chair [[Ben Bernanke]].

title: Xochitl Torres Small
deleted: Torres Small ran once again in the [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in New Mexico|2020 election]]. She lost to the same 2018 competitor, Herrell, becoming one of a multitude of 2018 Democratic freshmen to fall to Republican competition in an election which was combined with the [[2020 United States presidential election|presidential election]].
